reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is BY FAR the most polished game I have ever seen on Steam Early Access. There are so many heap of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• games being churned out right now, this is just a breath of fresh air. Very glad I bought into the game. 9/10.

The Good
- The game has very smooth controls and fun movement.
- Lots of guns that are really satisfying to use.
- FOV Slider.
- Really visually appealing.
- Easy to use dedicated server tools

The Bad
- XP System easily exploited
- Rocket is insanely overpowered. (You need to reduce the splash radius (or the damage) and maybe    even reduce the fire rate by a margin because it is a bit too easy to kill people).
- Head hitboxes are way too big, you can hit people with the outside of your crosshair on their head.
- The pistol is a joke, so when you spawn you really have to avoid people.
- Play will be very limited until the new maps come out, but I am happy to wait.

The Ugly
- Me

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A throwback to 90's gaming culture, TOXIKK is an arena shooter with bright, neon colors, and a puzzling level design that favors corners over open fields, and promotes fast paced gameplay with powerful weapons. Even in its early stages with only one map (this review is written as of 0.73 Wasabi), the game shows a balanced arsenal where one doesn't even feel guilty for using the rocket launcher.

Although many players may have already been introduced to the genre, TOXIKK holds its appeal for new players that freshen up the pool to add new experiences, and wage new wars. However, this comes at a price since the arena shooter genre has gone all but extinct since the 90's, with the last popular" arena FPS being Unreal Tournament III in 2006
date: which was poorly recieved due to its unbalanced weapons and poor movement.\n\nHowever
recommended: TOXIKK features improved movement in comparison to UT3
hoursPlayed: and again
voteText: a more balanced arsenal where a player is encouraged to utilize all weapons at their disposal. With the development team faithfully taking the opinions of the players to heart
helpfulPercent: weapon balance is still being perfected even now.\n\nA nostalgia trip for old school gamers
votesHelpful: and a new experience that completely abandons that of modern shooters for the new generation
votesTotal: TOXIKK is an amazing game that revitalizes its genre with fast paced action and impressive graphics (for an indie game especially). Reakktor Studios is putting their money where their mouth is
votesFunny: and indeed letting us "Frag like it's 1999"!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all: Toxikk is in an early state currently. The first Early Access build has been released about a day ago and the developers included one single map only - on purpose. This is because they focus on basic gameplay and weapon balancing at the moment, which will be done based on community feedback. However, new content will be released every 2-4 weeks. Reakktor have posted a detailed release plan on the official forums, which can be found here:
http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=993

I'll try to update this review as new content gets released.

So here's my current opinion:

I knew this would be a very early release and hence I had my doubts about how playable and enjoyable it would be and how smooth it would work from a technical perspective. The download was about 800 MB only (including the dedicated server files), so I was very curious about what I would get to see.

Well, what should I say? Everything works just perfectly! I experienced no crashes at all. Graphics are smooth and beautiful despite my rather old system (Win7 64, Phenom II X4 CPU @3400 MHz, 8 GB RAM, Radeon HD 5800 graphics card with 1 GB). I play in full HD at high graphics settings and get no stuttering at all.

The game actually comes with a single player mode called Blood Arena" where you can play against adjustable bots. If you set the number of combatants to 1
date: you will be alone in the map and can try out everything you want while taking your time. Once you're fed up with fragging bots
hoursPlayed: you can play on the internet
voteText: as well as on your own LAN. In both variants
helpfulPercent: you have the choice to create a listening server (where others can join while you're playing as well) or join another server (listening or dedicated). So playing a LAN game with your friends is really easy
votesHelpful: for example.\n\nThe gameplay as such is very fluid. There's double jumps
votesTotal: dodging
votesFunny: dodge jumps and wall dodge jumps (exactly as in UT2004). At the moment
commentsCount: there are 7 weapons in the game including rocket launcher
column16: sniper
column17: flamethrower
column18: shotgun
column19: pistol and some more. The rocket laucher (called Cerberus) is somewhat overpowered in its current state
column20: but I'm sure this will be fixed with the next release as weapon balancing is one of the main goals currently. You also can't access the options while being in a map yet
column21: so the first setup is somewhat of a hassle. But once you're done with this
column22: it's all ok. This will be improved as well for sure.\n\nApart from this
column23: I'm really impressed how well everything works. Playing the game is great fun already - even if there's just one map (called "Foundation") right now. The menu
column25: weapons and map design is outstanding in my opinion and the sounds and music fit very well too. All players have equal chances as there's no such thing as DLCs
column26: micro transactions and the like. To me it seems that this really could be the start of a true 1999 Arena FPS revival with up-to-date visuals.\n\nI've been in the developer forums for some months now and I can really say that they have the right attitude towards the community
column27: development and marketing. They have made everything as transparent as possible (as you can see with the  beta roadmap linked above
column29: free dedicated servers for everybody and the possibility to create your own clan in the game (not included yet) have been implemented as a result of community feedback - before the game even became available in Early Access.\n\nJust 1 1/2 days after EA start
column30: there are many active players and people trying to build up a community already. You can find Steam groups
column34: IRC channels and so on.\n\nTo conclude this lengthy review: I recommend getting this game asap and frag like it's 1999. ;) But keep in mind that EA has just started and the full content will be available in 4-6 months only."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Toxikk is a brilliant game, a throwback to the good old days of arena shooters, if you've played Unreal Tournament or Quake you can immediately catch a grip of this game espcially since it borrows so heavily from UT which is not really a bad thing considering how well made the game is and the lack of modern arena shooters.

Graphically Toxikk is a very pretty looking even for an early access has very few bugs and glitches, its biggest flaw is perhaps its gun play while the gun looks great the sound decent and the player feedback during firing isnt exactly on point also only 3 maps as of this posting so hopefull by release both these issues will be solved.

The biggest problem and perhaps the most biggest turnoff is the online community is literally dead you'll barely notice more than 3 servers with users playing so hopefully by launch the game will have a decent user base so you can play games online.

Update (21/3/2016) - devs are supporting the game but this really needs a free weekend or something similar and needs to get out early access alreay so people tha dont buy early access titles can grab it.The servers are up but the have max 6-7 players at its peak in off time there are literally 0 players playing the game and the game has been in early access for more than a year now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this game for a while and trying out most of the maps and difficulty settings, I have but one question for the developers:

WHERE THE @#$@ HAS THIS GAME BEEN ALL MY LIFE!?


It looks like Halo,

It has the vehicluar Combat of Unreal Tournament,

It has the gameplay of Quake,

And it has the radical music of many 90s era video games.


What it doesn't have is:

-Quickscoping

-ADS Mechanics

-Sprint Mechanics

-Whiney 12 year olds

-Knife/melee button


The game has no decent online competitve play, but that is to be expected in Early Acess. As long as the developers keep up the good work and stay far away from microtransactions and map packs as possible, my review will remain VERY positive.

However, what I want to see included in the game is:

-More working, full servers.

-More maps

-More player customization items

-Customizable Music tracks


Overall, I am VERY happy with my purchase, and I would like to thank the developers for making such a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**First Impressions**

This game is really good. It's still Beta so don't expect GOTY right now, but I wouldn't be suprised if it got it at a later date.

Gunplay is perfect. The weapons remind me of Quake and UT and that's exactly what I was hoping for. Right now there is only one map, and it's a rather small one, so I can't really say much for map design but the current map seems pretty well-designed.

Graphics: 10/10

Gunplay: 10/10

Movement: 9/10 - Takes a little getting used too, haven't tried strafe jumping yet but I feel like it might work.

All-in-all it's a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Toxikk is everything I want in a arena shooter and the way Steam Earlyer Access SHOULD be done. They've used this model not as a way to pay for their game to be made, but for beta testing and polishing for full release.

The game currently only has one map availible but according to their roadmap they should be coming out with a new one twice a month. Reason for this seems to be for testing and balencing, instead of the maps just plain not being finished.

I honestly think that Toxikk might be the game to finally give the arena shooter that shove to come back from the grave.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Toxikk is the game I have been waiting 8 years for.

Pros
Back to the glory days
For those that weren't say...born yet, in 1999, the arena FPS might actually be a bit of an alien concept to you.

No regenerating health, no reloading, guns floating around on the maps, no cover-based combat, no progression, no OP level-restricted guns, and none of that killstreak nonsense.

Double jumping, directional dodging, wall dodging, fast gameplay, varied weapons, and mother‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing Redeemer 2.0!

Great Optimization

Devs that actually care

Sound assets are excellent

Exciting weaponry - Finally, alternate fires are back!
Also, it's about damn time FPS characters found their backpacks that can store 10 weapons at once.

Mod Support!

ConsAs much as I'd love to say Toxikk is a flawless game, it's not.
It has its issues. But, it's early access, it shouldn't be a surprise (I just wish some of the negative reviewers would realise that)
Playerbase is small (for now)

Bot AI can be quite silly
Especially common on CTF maps. They'll take the flying vehicles, fly them to the nearest open area, then spin around in circles until they are shot down

Thankfully, nothing gamebreaking.

Few maps

No announcer
If only there were some aspiring modders willing to bring back the glorious Double Kill!, Headshot!, GODLIKE etc. etc.
Hinthint.
If you are, or ever have been, a fan of arena FPS, you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying this.
If you feel like the slower gameplay of CoD and Battlefield are getting a bit dull, you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying this.
If you do not own Toxikk, you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying this.

Please guys, buy this game. There aren't many devs out there this deserving of your hard earned $, and any arena FPS fan will want to see this game strive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Facts:
Twitch-arena shooter (unreal tournament, quake, counterstrike) with the classic double-jumping and jump-dodging.

Opinions:
Pro:
Twitch-arena shooter (unreal tournament, quake, counterstrike) with classic double-jumping and jump-dodging, FINALLY.
The controls are excellent.
The grahpics are essentially a flashier, smoother, more detailed UT3 scheme.
The map design is classic quake/unreal and that is a good thing (lots of levels and uniform corridors).
Gameplay is smooth, thanks in part to the smooth controls, and movement is intentional.
The weapons are rewarding to use and feel perfect for their designs.

Con:
There is only one map at the moment
The game can crash occassionally
The weapons are limited.

Early Access Review

Well, here we are. Toxikk has come out and guys. I can't believe I'm saying this, but maybe certian Early Access titles have tainted my viewpoint of EA games. But, Toxikk is incredible in the state that it's in. It feels pretty much like a finished product. Despite obvious content issues.

So far the game is fast paced, furious and relentless. I really like the XP element which unlocks cosmetics, but also encourages a competitive element to your personal self. It feels good, the options menu is great, the FOV slider goes up to 120 from 90. Which is nice but I'd like to see it go up to 150, the sound track is excellent and it's really killer.

It's really promising especially at this early access launch state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Link to Video Review

EDIT:

Video Regarding Update V0.71

Video Regarding Update V0.73

Video Regarding Update V0.75

Video Regarding Update V0.80

I will summarize here what I say in the video. In it's current early access state, Toxikk already has more polish and replayability than many AAA titles, even with only one map and two game modes. There are obvious tweaks that could be made, and a lot of room for more content, but Toxikk has by far the best foundation for a simple shooter that I have played in a long time.

Pros:
+Boot Camp (Local Bot Matches)
+Classic Arena Shooter Gameplay
+Stable Servers
+High amount of customizable graphical settings
+No FREE TO PLAY

Cons (More like Small Gripes)
-High ping on may servers (I'm in the Eastern US)
-Only one playable map as of now, not very suited for team games
-Rocket launcher can be an annoyance
-Limited Player Customization
-No true controller support (wouldn't recommend one anyway unless you have a handicap)

Would I recommend this game to the mass public? At this time, absolutely not. However, if you want to support a developer that seems committed to a revival of a genre, this is likely one of the safest early access games on the market.

TL;DR: If you'e unsure, watch and wait. If you want to support Reakktor Studios, do it. This is the best early access game I've picked up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the first time in a while, I'm actually enjoying an online FPS --and this game isn't even finished. What does that say about the mainstream gaming industry? I appreciate this game because it goes back to basics. There's something about the simplicity in the combat and weapons system that is volumes more satisfying than any of the Triple-A blockbuster games in the genre today.

I've been enjoying myself. I discovered that I very rarely found myself ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off or bored. Why?

***INCOMING RANT***

Because there is no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t in this game -- just as the developers have stated. There are no level 99, prestige 256, plays-this-more-than-he-goes-outside, 13-year-old, pissants, who apparently f**** everyone's mothers on a game-by-game basis, with completely decked-out gold-plated, diamond encrusted, Dorito (TM) sponsered, akimbo, rapid-fire, Panzerschrecks. There is no godforsaken, pay-to-win, microtransaction system. There are no killstreak-rewarded weapons of mass destruction. There are no premium-edition, day-zero, spend another $50 for the complete game experience, downloadable weapons/ maps. No ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t.

This game reminded me why I originally fell in love with the FPS genre. It has brought me back to a time before a bi-annual Call of Duty release. Before Battlefield 5: Give Us Your Wallet. Before anyone gave a damn about the color you customized the laces on your soldier's boots.

It has brought me back to a time of Halo CE. A time of Counter Strike. A time of Unreal Tournament.

***END RANT***

I don't get mad when someone nails me in the head with a shot from their sniper rifle from miles away because I know that it took skill. In fact, I'm impressed by it. This game goes back to the time-honored tradition of shooting first and shooting precisely. The frag goes to the person with a truer aim. Not to the guy with better perks or a superior weapon unlocked late in the game. Everybody has an equal chance to use any weapon. You just have to find it on the battlefield first.

In short, this game is fair and fun. It is a FPS in the most traditional sense. I can only hope that Toxikk will spark a resurgeance of the traditional, competitive first-person shooter. Although, it isn't complete yet, it will be well worth the $20 and then some.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More polished in Beta than most recent AAA games.
Seriously though, this game is FUN, I dont think ive had so much fun with an FPS in a while!

Quick summary:

Dedicated Servers, none of the p2p ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

If you want to stay alive, you HAVE to move, but you have to be able to hit moving targets at the same time.

There is more to the game than just moving and shooting, press F to play dead and escape from a firefight, or lie dead and spring up like a trap to unsuspecting players. Press Q to enable a temporary cloak (Maybe 3 Seconds?) and sneak up on your prey.

This game is a prime example of the beauty of Unreal Engine. The lighting, reflections, textures, particles, etc are all gorgeous. Honestly one of the most beautiful Unreal Engine games I've seen.

The music in this game is just perfect. When I first hopped into a match I didnt spawn just so I could hear the whole intro track, that dirty bass just fits the theme so well.

This game runs as smooth as warm butter (at least on my PC), I have had NO framedrop or performance issues whatsoever.

There are a few issues though:

The sensitivity slider is no joke.

There is no Borderless Window option, and sometimes it can take a few tries to get your settings to stick.

You cannot change options/settings while in a match, you have to leave the match entirely to change settings (unless maybe you can in the console, not sure though). FIXED

The game did crash once, but started up again with no problems.

Some of the weapons need a bit of rebalancing.

Cerberus (Rocket Launcher) needs a damage nerf (He who owns the cerberus, owns the match) FIXED

Raven (Basic Pistol) needs a fire rate boost
I can 100% reccomend this game to anyone looking for Quake/UT style fast-paced FPS arena action. Just remember that at this moment there is only 1 map and 8 guns.
voteText: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TOXIKK Early Access Review (Steam Version)
This game definately brings back some fond memories.

UT 99, Quake, Half - Life, LAN Parties, Dial-Up, The dreaded phone call.

Man, i miss games like this...

Talking about the game itself though, i can highly recommend this to anyone who used to bash the hell out of games such as Unreal Tournement.

At the moment though the game does not have everything implemented yet, the only arena that is available for playing is 'Foundation' a somewhat China Town style map, which is infact quite spacious and highly detailed.

There are a few things that make the game unbalanced at the moment, mainly the 'Cerberus', which is an automatic Rocket launcher and can be quite a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to get past when there is a player dominating with it on a game server. But in the upcoming patches things are going to be scaled up and down so that it feels a lot more comfortable.

Anyone that is a fan for Character Customization, this game has a few bits and bobs that the player can play around with to tweak their character.

- Two selectable armor types [Factions]
- Glow Colours for lighting
- Patterns and Textures
- Armor Colours
- Clan Tag
- Name Tag

Although it may not seem like much there will hopefully be more on the way to look forward to.

Toxikk has options for 'Mutators' Just like that in Unreal, I haven't had a look into any of them, if any yet. But Player created content is going to be widely available.

There seems to be a ranking system in the game but, the XP seems to scale up infinitely so... Where that goes... I have no idea, Ranks and rewards will be most likely implemented later.

Other things that can be a little bit arsey with the game is the likes of it's optimization and support for other platforms such as MAC & Linux, but apart from that...

In a nutshell, the game is fantastic, has brilliant visuals, isn't 'pay 2 win' or 'free 2 play' and is definately a fully skill based shooter.

- Windowlicker -

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game tries to sell its self as a competitive arena FPS similar to those of the 90's era. However that's really where it falls short. Toxikk really has nothing in common with a proper arena fps and its really just another casual modern FPS game.

Here are the core problems.

* Over the top fog and post processing that cannot be disabled in online mode (see forum post:  http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=12&t=1400&p=13556#p13556)

* Film grain / HDR / Bloom / Post Processing / Distortion / Grain effect make visibility worse than even call of duty.

* Mouse acceleration and smoothing is difficult to remove, to fully remove it you have to change a number of config settings, these config changes tend to get overwritten if you don't set them to read only.

Seeing as this is an early access game, and this is the direction the developers have decided to take the game really disappoints me. I will update this review if any of these issues change, and hopefully they do.

I would personally avoid the game and go for a proper competitive fps like Reflex.

**EDIT 1**

I create a youtube video to demonstrate the differnces with fog on and off: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=381959609

**EDIT 2**

The dev's released an update today that fixed the visibility issues to some degree. The fog is still there however player models are much more visible now.

That was my main gripe with the game. The best solution is to totally remove the fog, but as its currently not as game breaking as before I'm going to change my update from not recommend to recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

READ A LOT OF REVIEWS BEFORE YOU BUY
I had to get a refund for this game. Thankfully the new Steam policy is more forgiving.

Like other reviews, this game truly is a ghost town. Going onto the forums, the devs have said they are holding off on promotion until the game is complete. Who knows how long that will be. But honestly- if you are going to make the game available, and nobody is playing an exclusively online multiplayer game, something is wrong. It shouldn't be an available product. There is very little content to speak of - one game type, small handful of maps. Getting people into the game now would still be very important I think?

I do actually like this game quite a bit. I played with bots and the visuals are amazing... but I'm worried for the future of this game. Will this ever get the player base it deserves? The early access might be damaging this game's reputation. Honestly, I would've liked to hold onto this in my Library and wait it out but if it doesn't even have enough content to hold onto a small player base then why is it available? Will people ever come back?

Other problems - the guns are severely unbalanced. The starting gun is extremely weak, the rocket launcher is a one hit kill. I can see how this would play out online.

The nostalgia wears off quickly and it would be nice for this game to have some original concepts to still move the genre forward without it feeling very outdated. Obv. there will likely be more of this in the future though, not enough content to be super harsh about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Halo and Advanced Warfare had an incredible baby that was forgotten about... This FPS game has the makings to be the best shooter around, unfortunately it seems nobody noticed this gem.

Toxikk has a pretty unique feature (As far as i'm aware) where you can ragdoll in order to trick your enemy into thinking your dead. This accompanied by the awesome level-design make this game very special amongst shooters, I have never found a shooter that feels this fluid and well-thought-out. The vehicles are also really cool, there is a vehicle ability thing where you can simply summon a bike to drive, it has a cool-down timer and can also be used as a very fun and interesting weapon!

Overall I would have to say this game has so so SO much potential, but there are no public servers for this game, so if you wanna play this game I recommend finding a big group of people to play with, if you decide you wanna give this game a try shoot me an invite to your game, I am always looking for more people to play this with!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's early days yet, but this has some genuine potential to become a classic arena-shooter. Brought me back to the good old UT days and it'll be interesting to see what the developers can do with the vehicular combat promises. It looks like a triple-A release from last gen, which isn't meant as a criticism. It's pretty.

There are all the old-school movement and twitch-responses here and the weapons feel meaty and give plenty of kick. It's nice to be able to customise the avatars too and I think the developers have taken the right track with awarded-exp going towards rank upgrades.

I can see myself coming back to this game regularly and I'm looking forward to how it develops in future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is Early Access and the Devs are doing things right.

With that being said, do I think they should not have published to STEAM yet and just sent out Alpha or Beta downloads? Yes. I'm afraid the negative reviews due only to lack of players will offset the recommendation for when the game is released. And this is a great game. The servers used to be packed.

Are the servers empty? Yes. However, the devs are constantly active on the forum and don't want to market the game until they feel it's ready. This isn't other Early Access titles where the devs release a crappy game and vanish with your money. This game is ready to play but has limited maps. The devs are active and answer questions not only daily but HOURLY. During the last release it was a matter of minutes and seconds.

Really, in its current state, the game is an investment. Buy now at the $19USD and play it when it is finished and there is a higher playerbase. Or wait and pay what may be $50, because that's what the game is worth - that's what any other publisher would charge for this game in its completion.  Don't expect to purchase the game now and begin fraggin immediately. I know that sucks, I really do, but it is what it is.

It's up to you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this on and off only to find a mixed bag in every update I think it's time I expressed my true thoughts on Toxikk. Yes I am aware it still has the Early Access label on it, but at this point the game is pretty much on the path of being complete. I doubt the game will change much after this review so I expect it to be at least valid until somewhere around 2017.

So where to start? Toxikk is a game attempting to bring 90's skill based shooters back into the mix, which seems to be growing more and more within today's industry despite the E-sports MOBA dominance. Developed by Reakktor (the typos are strong with this one) their game runs on the Unreal engine. Their task is welcomed by many FPS fans such as myself, unfortunately the game simply isn't up to snuff when compaired to games like Quake 3 Arena and it's expansion Team Arena or Unreal Tournament.

Now why is that? The game does a good job of playing like an Arena FPS but with a couple new features and weapons (although the weapons really aren't all that fresh) the answer is simply where the game is going, I just don't agree on a lot this game is trying to do. There is too much attention paid to graphical eye candy rather than the design of the map. For example the new map Citadel is a redux of Facing Worlds from Unreal Tournament. However it has been forged in a way where it's just overly complex and rather annoying to get anywhere on the map. One of the joys in Facing Worlds was how simple yet very competetive it's map design was. Now the flag sits on top of a metalic mountain of a building where your chances of getting off are slim to damn nill.


Let's talk about the audio. I gave Reakktor a break thinking they were just place holder sounds and music...I was sadly mistaken. The weapons have no kick, no punch at all to them. This is an FPS mind you, one of the base objectives if not map quality would have to be the sounds of your gun. Once again this could be changed but after talking to one of the developers about their sound they feel it's perfectly fine. Which is great, for them. I of course disagree with them but I have little say in the matter.

As for the music this was another complaint i had for the developer. The base tracks you hear a majority of the time are just generic. There's no adreniline rush to the music like Quake or Unreal Tournament. Instead it sounds more like dance music of today, really cheap dance music.
Although the new tracks this update has brought in are pretty good, they sound like they would fit in more with a cyber punk RPG such as Deus Ex, rather than an Arena FPS however.

Finally weapon variety. Basically all they did was take existing weapons from UT and Quake then fused them together. The Sting Ray is basically the plasma gun from Quake with the Shock Rifle's primary fire thrown in as a secondary fire. I understand there is only so much they could do with the guns, but I would rather play with UT weapons than these...

Do I suggest this game? It's hard to say. I like Toxikk and it's plan but it's not excuted properally to call it a soul successor to Unreal or Quake. I suggest getting the game on sales, it's just not worth the full price when you can get Quake and Unreal for cheaper.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Quake III Arena and Unreal Tournament 1999 for as long as I can remember and I had tons of fun with those games. They felt... different, but in a good way. Both games did multiplayer in different ways to eachother and they are examples of multiplayer done correctly: fast paced, neverending action and a whole arsenal of weapons. The great thing is that they still hold up in terms of gameplay. Since then, I feel no other game did multiplayer quite as great as Q3A or UT1999 but I remained patient to see if there would be another game like them. And it was worth the wait.

TOXIKK claims to be a spiritual successor to the FPS giants of the late 90s and early 2ks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TOXIKK had serious potential. It couldve been the next Unreal Tournament, or sparked the return of old-school shooters. But unfotunately, TOXIKK has been plauged by numerous issues both within and outside of the game:

1. Lack of Content and Updates

You think Killing Floor 2 has little content, or has slow development? TOXIKK blows KF2 out of the water with lack of content and lack of good updates. There was ONE map at launch with 2 very similar modes: FFA and TDM. They did add another map shortly thereafter, but thats about it. The devs have seemingly abandoned TOXIKK in favor of promoting Friday Frag Fest notifications every 4 minutes...

2. The Game is Dead, No Community

There was a fairly healthy number of players on the *very first day*. Emphasis on *first day*, because the community quickly died off. Why, you may ask? Well, not only was there ONE map, but the Rocket Launcher weapon (can't remember the name) was so overpowered that whoever had it was garunteed the match win. The only people who got ANY kills whatsoever were bunny hopping while spamming the Rocket Launcher. They did nerf the ever lasting hell out of it later, but the game was dead on arrival thanks to not only the severre lack of content, but the sheer power of the Rocket Launcher.

3. The Developers are very Unprofessional

This one is quite controversial, but i will try my best to remain neutral. At first i loved these guys because of their very blunt marketing of TOXIKK as a return to Old-School Arena shooters of the late 90s. In fact, TOXIKK's taline is Frag Like It's 1999"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm impressed. This is probably the most polished Early Access game I've ever played, and also one of the best-looking ones as well. Especially for an indie developer. The game is perfectly stable, crash-free, and runs smooth as silk on my PC. Was able to set my options and join an online match within seconds, no problems whatsoever. The game runs on Unreal Engine 4.

It has all of the settings you would expect from a proper PC game. World detail, shadow detail, light shafts, AF level, multiple forms of anti-aliasing, different framerate caps, V-sync, and FOV slider that can go well over 100. I'm playing it on the Very High" preset with a few extra tweaks. I'm sure I can run it on "Ultra" just fine
date: but I haven't bothered trying yet. It's such a fast-moving game that there isn't much point in stopping to admire the pretty graphics (but it's a very pretty game anyway).\n\nThe menus are laid out well
recommended: the server browser is slick and functional
hoursPlayed: and - as I said - the whole game feels extremely polished.\n\nFans of Quake and Unreal Tournament will feel right at home here. The devs have been pretty straightforward about their resentment toward F2P games and microtransactions. There's no leveling
voteText: loadouts
helpfulPercent: XP
votesHelpful: or any other "modern" FPS features. No sprinting
votesTotal: no ADS. Bunnyhopping is alive and well. The rocket launcher is the most devastating weapon in the game (as it should be)
votesFunny:
but it's not fast enough or explosive enough that it doesn't require skill.

The weapon spawn points actually have a timer floating above them to show when they will respawn. A clever feature that I have never seen in an arena shooter before.

The one little gripe I had is that I couldn't modify my settings during a match. Had to back out to the main menu to change my mouse sensitivity. A bit frustrating but something you'll only have to deal with once.

The other thing I should point out

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall Rating: 9.7/10

This is such a simple little arena shooter and yet, I see myself in the future, jumping on top of people's heads right before they explode into oblivion from the onslaught of powerful pellets propelled from my Bullcraft, simply by clicking Mouse 2, or I watch as someone's head is turned into a red mushy melon-like substance when I Dodge-Jump around the corner, only to do a complete Ten-Eighty and scope in with the Falcon, mere milliseconds before the trigger is pulled.

Moving on...this game runs extremely well. I'm certain hardware from 2012 and above will have no issues playing this game. Two Game Modes and One Map is fine by me. Tweak what you have now, and work your way up to bigger things, it's better than throwing it all out on the table from the get-go, only to have none of it work or be worth anything.

For an Early Access title, you'd expect there to be hundred of bugs and glitches that need fixed or tweaked. This is not the case here, as I doubt you'll find more than a few minor bugs here and there, and since you have console access, you can most likely fix your issues from there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of v0.75:
TOXIKK wants to be new Unreal Tournament.
And while it's still quite rough around the edges, it is definitely getting there.
The combat is quick, fun and all about learning maps, honing your reflexes and learning how to use dodge jumps.
No progression means everyone's equal at any time. And for me personally that's a very cool thing (at least I can't make an excuse that someone has higher level than me and that why I suck xD).
There are only two maps in the game, but they do show that devs know what they are doing - maps are very well designed, nicely balanced for all the game modes you can run them on, have enough space for close combat as well as for long range encounter, and of course look pretty cool.
The game code seems to be quite solid - I rarely had dips below 60 fps. And the ones that happened seemed to be related to particle emitters.
Cell capture mode (that is essentially CTF) is pretty awesome too. Mostly because of the huge map with vehicular combat and all the crazy stunts you can pull off.

So, if you like old-school arena FPS games - I'd definitely recommend TOXIKK.
And if you think that 3 game modes and two maps are not enough, then just add it to your wishlist and keep an eye on it. It is pretty damn enjoyable.

On the downsides:
- Game features only three modes and two maps at the moment
- Vehicles are behaving a bit whacky from time to time
- Looks like weapons that emit a lot of particles (mainly flamethrower) currently crash the game
- For some reason game has mouse smoothing on by default (although it's barely noticeable)

More detailed look in the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BY6o3eKB-HY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The two biggest complaints that this game seems to have are these:
1. no one on the public servers.
2. minimal amount of content.

Both of these are accurate assessments at this juncture (release 0.89, 22 Sep 2015). However, this game has two very poignant counterarguments:

1. It's *stable*, and the content is *polished*. The game has never crashed on me, and even with the settings basically-maxxed out, it runs butter smooth on my laptop (core i7, 16GB RAM, SSD, GeForce 965M). There are only a handful of maps, but they load nicely, look great, make sense, and I've never run into a geometry issue or other annoyance.
2. LAN. This game actually works over a LAN. This is something that so few games have these days, which annoys me, because I love getting together with my friends and having a frag fest in the same room.


I'll also add a few other minor nitpicks:
1. Weapon balance could stand a bit of tweaking. The default gun is about as effective as a marshmallow launcher, while the rocket launcher will kill basically anyone in one shot, even with a whole-lot-of-health. Similarly, health power-ups are very sparsely littered around most of the maps, so death is near-constant.
2. The AI could use a bit of improvement. Playing against bots seems to go from they'll run in highly predictable patterns
recommended: and ignore your existence when you're shooting them" to "you'll never make it five steps out of the base before you get killed with a headshot from halfway across the map".\n3. Vehicle maps aren't yet optimized. Most of them are extremely large
hoursPlayed: taking a long time to traverse. The land vehicles have some handling issues
voteText: and getting from one side of the map to the other takes a while on foot
helpfulPercent: due to the lack of a translocator or hoverboard kind of mechanic to help speed things along.\n\nNone of my nitpicks are actual show stoppers
votesHelpful: if you're an Unreal Tournament fan (especially the underrated UT3
votesTotal: which is unsurprising given Toxikk's use of the engine)
votesFunny: you'll feel right at home in this game that seems to take the tenets of the UT series (clearly its inspiration) and give it an overhaul in all the right places. I look forward to the forthcoming content and system optimizations
commentsCount: but even with its handful of maps and modifiers
column16: it's worth the asking price - especially if you're looking for a game that supports LAN play."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game would be incredible if people played it. Unfortunately I bought into the product thinking there would be some community. There is, in fact, no community. The community is dead. D-E-A-D. Dead.

I genuinely feel this is a solid product but even I as the developer would cease supporting it (and god have mercy on the souls of the developers that do) without any current players.

Granted the game isn't ACTUALLY released yet; as is scheduled for Early Access, the fact nobody is playing the game should not stop the developers from completing the product and giving it an official release.

The null quantity of players now should not be indicative of what the product has the potential to be - since you can't really stipulate a 'currently active playerbase' within reason to an Early Access game (because it's a game which isn't released yet). For that reason only I give TOXIKK a positive review (it's unfair to give a negative review to a product which isn't released yet based on its early access playerbase, since you shouldn't really say a game has a playerbase at all until it's released).

But god knows how long that will be, if at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game takes me back to a time when Quake, Half-Life, and Unreal Tournament owned my multiplayer fragging world. It's fast-paced, the weapons are familiar, and both the visuals and audio are excellent.

As of the time I write this, there are only two maps. I've played the crap out of the deathmatch map, and I've only started playing the capture the flag map. Both are lots of fun. I'm also very interested in the introduction of vehicles with the CTF map; they remind me a bit of Halo.

Assuming that the developer continues to add maps, modes, and mutators, I highly recommend the game's purchase when it goes gold. Until then, if you're willing to take a chance on early access and you don't mind a small subset of gameplay, I also recommend purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hilariously bad name, surprisingly good game; iTzxxTOXIKK420xx is fast-paced and a decent amount of fun for being something in Early Access. As the game's description outlines, it plays much closer to older games like Quake or Unreal Tournament (incorporating things such as map placement of weapons as opposed to preset loadouts and non-regenerating health) and ends up being a refreshing change of pace from what you get with a lot of online shooters these days. However, considering there's only one map and the weapon balance/map placement is still being worked out I'd probably recommend people to wait for a couple updates just to have a bit of variety and not get burned out on playing it before the game's at its full potential. Regardless though, the core gameplay is entertaining and it seems like there's a lot of promise in this for anyone that just wants an Unreal Tournament-style game to get into so it may still be worth checking out if only to see the solid foundation the developers have laid.

And who knows, maybe they'll call it something else by the time it officially releases; otherwise you might want to boot up some eroge like Sakura Angels or a valley girl simulator - such as the critically acclaimed Barbie Dreamhouse Party - before jumping on here and save yourself the embarrassment of your friends seeing you playing something that sounds and looks like a bad Xbox Live gamertag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great old-school arena shooter with weapons that all have their own strategies to be effective, twitch-timing and fast movement, lots of mutators, and a surprisingly lively playerbase--with one caveat.

You won't see other players until you spend a half hour or so in a server with a friend. Lobby-based games kinda killed server-lurking, and Toxikk requires some server-lurking to see it shine. Get a full 8v8 match with real people, and it turns into a freakin' gem.

It's still got some rough edges, and if you're expecting something with modern weapon" values
date: you're best served to look elsewhere. Toxikk is tooled around spamming rockets
hoursPlayed: and not blinking for five minutes at a time. You'll probably see a lot of complaining about balance--but any player that remembers playing UT '99 when it was new will tell you that's a load. You'll see rockets
voteText: grenades

votesHelpful: shotgun blasts... and it's a riot. I nearly had an aneurism when I first read some of the threads cropping up about the rockets being OP--back in the day

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TOXIKK may be the best Early Access game I've ever played.

Being someone who still plays arena shooters on a regualr basis, I can say that as an arena FPS, TOXIKK is pure gold. If you've played UT and are familar with the dodge and movement mechanics, you will be familar with this game. Weapons feel great and the devs are taking weapon balance as their top priority, which is more than i can say for others.  Yes YOU Bungie.

Performance wise it runs perfectly fine on my middle-tier PC on around medium settings while still looking really damn nice. Bugs? I haven't encountered any. NONE.  Bots are included and function perfectly for those who want them.

The only con I can think of is that there is only one DM/TDM map at the time of writing. Vehicles and much bigger maps are on their way with regular updates.

In conclusion, this game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing awesome and kicking sand in the face of the plague that is the modern military shooter.

Highly Recommended.

Early Access Review

Although the game only went into beta, it's pretty clear it will be one of the best arena shooters ever made.

If you liked UT2004 you like TOXIKK. It basically uses the same movement model, so you won't have a hard time to adapt. The weapons are somewhat similar to the Quake Weaponset, so no surprises on this.

About the tech stuff:
The Game is built with the Unreal Development Kit, so it uses UE3. I run it w√≠th ~150 FPS on a i5-4570 & GTX770, no OC. Ofcourse such stuff is map dependant, and there is only one map so far. But it should give you a clue about the performance.

The game will evolve over the next few months, so make sure you check in from time to time. That is, if you're not fully into it already! See you ingame!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of Unreal Tournament series since the first version I am extremely happy with Toxikk! This is true continuation of UT style (and not unintentional, obviously - lots of direct hints there, like the infamous Deck 16 map from original UT, which has been Deck 17 in UT2004 and simply Deck (18?) in UT3 is now Dekk 19 in Toxikk - and what a Dekk it is! It is probably even better than the original, which is barely possible). This is what we've been expecting (and didn't get) from UT3. It‚Äôs finally here!

But most important is that even if one disregards the whole UT franchise thing, Toxikk is a very good looking and very well performing (even at this pre-release stage) game, which is very fun to play. What more can you ask for?

Well, perhaps a bit more content, but more on that later.

Just like UT, there are several game types, a variety of nice weapons which are fun to use and all have alternative fire modes, a vehicles with different specializations (including ground and aerial vehicles) and some with external seats for shooters besides driver. And the trademark ‚Äúmore moderate than Q3 but still faster than CoD/CS‚Äù game pace which I‚Äôve been missing so much since UT2004.

Besides that, the visuals in the game are stunning. Everything looks beautiful and professionally designed - weapons and projectiles, vehicles, maps (hell, Dekk maps is a work of art). The virtual world of Toxikk is a pleasure to be in even if you get your butt kicked by other players :-)

So again, I‚Äôm very happy with this game and I couldn‚Äôt recommend it more.

Regarding the content though: the sole notable downside of Toxikk is the lack of maps. There are just a handful at the moment, and only one that has vehicles (Twin Peaks).

Also somewhat notable is lack of vehicles (there's scorpion cross hellbender with UT3 style eject+self-destruct (which is total fun) but hellbender style weaponry, there's a raptor cross cicada thing, and there's some manta-like hover tank, but that's it - no tanks or other slow heavy vehicles) and game types (I know Last Man Standing is soon to come, along with some Duel whatever it is - but no Assault, which is a pity - it was a true highlight of UT, and most sad - no Onslaught, which is a best game type and true highlight of UT2004 IMO).

But I expect more content to be there at the release and some more to arrive later - as DLCs perhaps, and of course some third party content from workshop. There are already some third-party maps in the workshop, and they are very good (an absolutely amazing version of Grendelkeep for Toxikk, a very stylishly Borderlands like looking Novus map, and a smaller space massacre FusionKKore map, which is clearly inspired by UT'99 DM-Fractal - well, not directly but by it‚Äôs UT2004 version DM-Gael, which author did mention in comments). So I‚Äôm not getting any points off Toxikk for that, because I expect this issue to go away eventually.

And thus final verdict is - 10/10. Get it. Now. The 4-pack.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well this took over my weekend to say the least. I'll try to keep this short; if you like Arena FPS games, then this is a safe purchase. The controlls are tight, weapons feel great and are a lot of fun to shoot, and graphics and sounds are top of the line.

Tons of great options and customisation, but sadly not when you are in game. And for those who want the real oldschool look may have to change a few things in a config file. I have encountered one major bug, and thats the gamecrash if you click and move your mouse a lot befor the serverlist has loaded up completly. But nothing more then that. It runs at 220 fps on my GTX 980 and seems to be very well optimised, and sets a good standard for early access games.

There is only one map at the moment (luckily a very good one), and there is some weapon balancing to be made for sure. Yes the rocketlauncher is silly and way to easy to get in such a tight map. But other then that, flawless! 10/10!!!
New maps, modes and weapons every 2-4 weeks according to the roadmap(link below), and i can't wait to see what else they have in store for this game!

Best FPS i have played in a good long while.

Roadmap:
http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=993

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Toxikk review  version .86

First Impressions
The game has just amazing graphics, with fun gameplay that is similar to the Original UT, and is just darn fun to play.

Lets start off with the graphics, this game has very good graphics, and uses ironically the Unreal Engine. I say Ironically because in my opinion this game is better than the last few Unreal Tournament games. This game runs about 30-40fps on my R9-m290x, depending on the  map milage varies. The texture detail is nice, what you would come to expect from a AAA UT release.

Game play is fun, it plays just like the original UT, with a few improvements that I think add a lot to the game.  Weapons feel a lot like they Did from UT, They look similar and function pretty much the same way they did. You're going to find yourself picking one up and say this is the Plasma Rifle. Some weapons vary a little, in the alternate fire modes, but they will feel familiar.

One of the little Improvements they made is after you kill an enemy they drop a health pack. What a simple reward for killing someone, it really prolongs the carnage. The health pack is available for anyone to pick up so if you are in the right spot at the right time you can grab that health pack after someone else‚Äôs kill, however the reverse is also true, wait too long and someone else will get it.


I think that the bot ai might be a have a steep learning curve, as on the easy setting (ridiculous ) they will literally walk by you and not even notice that you're there.Compared to that to higher difficulty and you see situations where Ai will mop you up pretty easily. This could just be my lack of experience with the game, but it seems that in order to get off the higher difficulty you're going to have to die a lot.

One of the things I can‚Äôt get over is just how much fun this game is to play. I have said it before but this game just is so much like the original UT the only way to get much closer is to Remake the Original using today's Graphics. The whole game just is familiar if you have played the original UT, the game play should just come to you naturally. I have also said that I think this is a lot better than Epic‚Äôs Newer UT, and I meant it  The game just has captured the core of what a Deathmatch FPS should be and ran with  it.

Right now there are several game modes, including Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, which are blood lust, Squad assault, and Cell capture, Read Deathmatch, team deathmatch, and CTF. Nothing special to note here other than they do have some vehicles in the game.They have put in a nice scoring system, for every kill you get you get x points, for and for every double kill, killing spree or whatever you may have gotten you get additional points. In capture the cell games a cell capture gets you points, so it might be possible to win the game just on the number of points.

Final thoughts.
More people need to buy this game and get in the online mode, just because the online play looks to be a little slow right now. That is just do to a total lack of players right now though. Buy this game and you wont regret it I promise.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRemember the good old days of Unreal Tournament? Where you and your buddies could just hook your computers up together and have a massive death match? Where there was no regenerating health or obnoxious constant voice chat? When an FPS was filled with silent characters that never talked, crazy guns and ridiculous speed and power? Well, if you do or if you're curious about a game like that, look no further than TOXIKK from Reakktor Studios: an indie that's a throwback to the old games of yore. The slogan in the description is ‚ÄúFrag like it's 1999,‚Äù and that's accurate statement to what the game is. Full Preview[www.noobfeed.com]

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRemember the good old days of Unreal Tournament? Where you and your buddies could just hook your computers up together and have a massive death match? Where there was no regenerating health or obnoxious constant voice chat? When an FPS was filled with silent characters that never talked, crazy guns and ridiculous speed and power? Well, if you do or if you're curious about a game like that, look no further than TOXIKK from Reakktor Studios: an indie that's a throwback to the old games of yore. The slogan in the description is ‚ÄúFrag like it's 1999,‚Äù and that's accurate statement to what the game is. Full Preview[www.noobfeed.com]
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA great throwback to the early FPS arena style games. Played during early access, there were certainly some hiccups with networking and multiplayer interaction, but I assume all will be ironed out come launch. If you're looking for a not-so-deep, traditional shooter that can take your mind off of things, look no further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was quite worried about supporting another early access game, but Toxikk was worth the jump.
It has a great ' roadmap ' for development, and the devs seem to listen to feedback.

If you enjoy arena-first person shooters, that are similar to Unreal Tournament or games without the mumbo-jumbo like COD, then this game is for you!

However, it only has one map, but in my opinion it is good enough to get a feel for the game. With 8 player modes and 16 players modes, normal deathmatch and team deathmatch.

First impression time!

Reakktor dead on deliver what they promissed. Frag like it's 1999."

Movement feels just like the classics (UT
date: Q3A). Some tweaking to the mouse settings and veterans feel at home within a handful of botmatches.\n\nThe first map might be a bit small

hoursPlayed: which can help you get away from hairy situations. But it has a well balanced reload time and limit of uses. It's a nice tactical element.\n\nLast but not least

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Heres a run down of why you should love TOXIKK Updated since ginger build

1. This game is sick with Stunning visuals even on the lower settings, as well as the smooth welll though out maps.
2. It has slick, smooth controls for mouse/keyboard aswell as for a 360 controller... what omg a pc gammer using a controller for shame...  don't judge guys maybe sometimes i like to lay on the bed or sofa and play or play away from home on my laptop where a track pad mouse dont cut it ny ways i rant
3. Its got bots with levels of difficulty so if your not the best you can practice on lower settings and ramp it up when your getting better.
4. Cheaper then main stream shooters like call of duty and battlefield.
5. Reminds me of halo.
6. Its still growing to be a great game cant wait to see the finished product :)
7. When it is released we wont be all grrr about bugs like BF4 as it will balanced and set up right :)
8. new game mode area domination
9. instagib settings and other mutators
10. kustome kontent make your own maps yes finaly we can have loads of cool UE maps to make already alot of maps have been made shame a few of them are the usual same old UT and quake remakes witch is fine id just rather see more original not remakes.
11. 2 new maps

DEKK

Dekk Looks amazing with its scifi tech theme with is neon blue lights in the wide corridors aswell as a little arena down the bottom  where theres a watery thing that kills you dont get me wrong by the corridoors theyr big enougth there are many bridges leading to higher ground  aswell as the hell raiser wepon is back and in this map you can rack aload of kills if timed right  its also smooth flowing with areas to control
this has to be my favriot map :) of all time

Castello
it looks like a old medivel town that has had fututreistic expansions built around it its quit fun to play
just feels out of place for the game

there are other fixes and things added but thos are the best :)

Now for the only down side its got a small player base.

But i do encourage you to buy this game for all the Reasons above
not for the negative as its a great game at heart and deserves a chance to become the next best arena shooter :)

hope this has been helpful if you wana play just add me and let me know that you wana play toxikk

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think everyone has been stung by an early access game at some in their gaming life.

TOXIKK is not like that. It runs on the tried, and tested Unreal Engine 3, and is well optimised for its early stages.

The devs are transparent, and know when they have made a mistake. For example, this is from the v0.73 patch notes: To have it only accessible outside of a match was pretty stupid
date: but if you work with a game for years
recommended:
you sometimes don't see the most obvious flaws."

It is good to see a dev admit a mistake so openly.

The beta roadmap is well planned out
hoursPlayed: and feature rich. - http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=993 - So far they have kept to their release schedule.\n\nThe game plays well
voteText: and is very reminiscent of arena FPS games of old. Everything feels tight
helpfulPercent: and well balanced.\n\nA must play from gamers who grew up with Quake
votesHelpful: and Unreal Tournament."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game kicks so much ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I have missed the days of old where you just get thrown into an area, grab a plasma rifle and start shooting like a maniac at your opponents. This is a true revival of the old FPS Arena setting that we have all come to love. I'm glad that the genre hasn't died out yet, and with gameplay, visuals and gunplay handling as well as it does here...i doubt it will for a very, VERY long time. Grab it, its worth it.

Keep in mind that it IS STILL an early access game, meaning obviously that most features aren't avaliable yet. You can check the patching scheduel here to see what is upcoming: http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=993

All in all, this game is a riot to play, and I say its worth the full price to help the developers keep on bringing more content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first early access/beta game I've bought where I immediately knew I got my money worth. For fans of the arena shooter genre, this is the best modern one available. It is still early right now and is in need of maps more than anything, but it is already a blast to play and worth every penny in my opinion.

Devs are also great and very interactive with the community (Go Sharkster!) and deserve support for this product. I expect many of the UT and quake community to migrate over in the future, except for the diehard fans that don't wanna see their games die. When the player count rises I could see this becoming a dominant shooter on our platform.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEarly Access Review (Wasabi Build): Arena FPS is a dying genre now amongst the casualized modern shooters of today. The genre definitely deserves to be revived and Reakktor Studios seems to have put forth much effort to help the cause. The game lends itself to the Unreal Tournament community more so than that of Quake with its double jumps, wall dodges, and weapons that each have a secondary fire mode. It's definitely a well polished game for Early Access and I can't wait to see what it has to offer in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great, frenetic fun. It reminds me of the first time I played Unreal Tournament. The graphics are great and for an early version, the balance is well done. People say this game type is dead and dated but after 10 years of COD and Battlefield, this over the top gameplay feels, quixotically, refreshing and nostalgic.

This release only has one level but it's so far held my attention for a few hours and I'm ready to play more. I can't wait for the next release, in February, that will introduce a super sized map with vehicles and CTF gameplay. It's going to be off the chain.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here's a short survey to find out if you want this game.

Do you like:
1. Unreal Tournament and/or Quake 3 Arena?
2. Freakingly fast paced shooting?
3. Fancy graphics?
4. Great controls?
5. Skill based games? (Can be quite hard as a beginner but crazy rewarding as you get better)
6. LAN play?
7. Great optimization?
8. Early access which is only missing some maps, weapons and such? (Only found one bug as of yet)

If you could answer yes to any of these questions (mostly 1, 2 and 5) then yes. I totally recommend getting this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first glance, this game looks like another UT3 (which we all know was awful). However, i was pleasantly surprised at how good it actually is (and could be) once more updates are released. This game is much further ahead than many other early access games and is in a very playable state, even if there is only 1 map right now.

The gameplay is very similar to UT2004, while fans of Quake will find a lot to like here, it is quite different and it's not quite as 'hardcore', meaning it's a lot easier for newcomers to jump in and start fragging. Do i recommend this game right now? Yes i do, however the content is low right now so it also wouldn't be a bad idea to wait for the February updates, when a few new game modes and maps will be added.

I have a great feeling about this game, with a few balance changes and the extra content (which is due very soon), this could be one heck of a game for arena fps fans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The simple fact that this game is early access makes it a deal breaker for some people, but do take these pros and cons into account if you are considering the early access to be worth the risk.
Pros:
-Bots
-Action PACKED
-Nice level design
-Old arena fps dodging, double jumping, no-reload sweetness
-Nice looking player models
-Likely to be a more finished product than most early access games due to the vision of development being so clear
Cons:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here are some honest Pros and cons:

pros:

-Fast paced
-Based on skill (Unless you're using the Cerebus)
-Graphically stunning
-Good old fashioned combat
-Good dedicated servers
-Amazing port
-Very responsive movement
-Good map design (Only 1 map but Its design is excellent)

Cons:
-THE CEREBUS (I will talk about this once I finish with the cons)
-Crashes when on server screen (I doubt it's my machine the things a beast)
-AGAIN THE CEREBUS
-Really should be more than one map. I know it's early access but I still paid for the game give me at least 3 maps.
-The lens flare on the lights is distracting
-Map hitboxs are inconsistent

THE CEREBUS - Let me start by saying that this is the reason I stopped playing. The Cerebus is a rocket launcher which you can pick up near the center of the map. It's an OP weapon which almost everyone uses. People would rather not use skill and instead use this OP weapon and think they're good because they're getting loads of kills. YOU CAN NOT USE ANT OTHER WEAPON BECAUSE THE CEREBUS IS BETTER. The damage of the weapon isn't the problem It's the firing rate of it. You can't escape it and it just ruins the game and until they tweak the weapon I'm not playing online because I'd rather use a veriaty of guns.

Overall the games great but maybe don't buy it yet... Just wait till the game has more than what it has so for

-Nostalgic Pickle

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say that when I first heard about TOXIKK I was skeptical to say the least, but intrigued nonetheless. After playing this for a few hours on a friends account (not mine if my current hours are any indication), I felt like I was playing UT/UT2k4 again or any good arena shooter, which is a relief from all the copy/paste military shooters out there (COD I'm looking at you). And don't get me wrong I enjoy my Battlefields or Tactical shooters/simulators (not battlefield) most of them (minus HL been playing them since 1942), but it is getting a little long in the tooth. Yes, I am well aware of the open source Quake/Quake clones (e.g. Quake Live, Nexuiz, Alien Arena, Warsow etc.), but they werent quite the same or no one plays it seems. It seemed like arena shooters were dead until I saw Tribes: Ascend but that eventually died too. It seemed like there weren't any new TRUE arena shooters to be found console or PC-wise ( well Halo is sort of, and I want to really stress sort of...)  And now finally the UT project is started and I have this now!!!

TL:DR If you want a fresh take on nostalgia buy it!

Movement (strafe jumping, jumping off walls) and basic maneuvers like rocketjumping feel very great and allow you to get to hidden areas of each map which usually carry either a certain high tier weapon or additional health/armor, exploring the map makes sense.
the base CTF mode combines vehicle (land and air) and infantry combat very well, because of the fast movement and the cloak ability you are still able to take out an enemy tank just keep in mind that if these players pay attention they can still take you out before you had the chance to fire with weaponry which you are going to need to take out these vehicles,these game modes rely on teamwork , from vehicles for multiple players to basic things like cover fire for the flag carrier or stabbing enemies in the back via cloak device, all weapons have a secondary fire mode, from burst rifles, flame bombs to nuclear missiles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm not going to give this a negative review, but at the same time, I don't think people should really buy it.

The game is fantastic: exactly the kind of throwback arena FPS it advertises itself as. If you're a fan of UT99, Quake 3, or any such games - you'll enjoy the gameplay.

The problem is, the game's been in Early Access for far too long with too few content (map) updates. The current map roster is acceptable for a new release but the multiplayer is already dead. It will be tricky to get that back without some substantial content updates.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDoesn't know what era of shooter it wants to be in or how it wants to go about it. It feels like a mix of quake, unreal championship, and Halo; but done very poorly. It's not balance or robust enough to play competitively, yet not big enough or have enough content to be played for fun. It's awkwardly trying to be something it can't with content (or multiplayer community) it doesn't have and an appeal to a market that wanted it so badly, just done right. Much like Sim City (5) syndrome; It's a let down that teases you until purchase with it's promises and pretty pictures. I'm better off going back to playing the games it's trying to be, at least they play right and have a respectable amount of players online.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR of pros/cons in the end.

TOXIKK is an Arena FPS that brings back the excellent gameplay from older titles such as Unreal Tournament and Quake, even though it's closer to Unreal then Quake (if that's good or bad that's for you to decide).

The controls and feels of your character is top notch, at first it kinda feel slow and sluggish but when you start getting used to the dodge mechanincs you feel like a super hero at times. The gunplay is satisfying and every weapon feels good to use, even though some of them are highly unbalanced at the current moment (looking at you Cerberus).

The graphics are great aswell as the artstyle, really fits the game.

So far there is only one map available which is a bummer but it's Alpha/Beta/Early Access/Whatever-you-want-to-call so it's not too much of a hassle. The map layout is good with some open areas and a lot of chokes and close corners that enforces" CQC
date:
kinda wish they would add a larger map aswell so we would have a bit more variety.

To sum it up:
Pros:
- Great and clutch controls
- Satisfying gun-play
- Good graphics
- A bit of fresh air from the current trend of modern military shooters
- Brings back memories of the good old days of Arena FPS's
- Good hitboxes and netcode (atleast what I've experienced)

Cons:
- Only one map
recommended:
will be fixed eventually.
- Unbalanced guns
- Seems to be a bug that when you spawn your gun doesn't pop up immedietly meaning you are defenseless for a few seconds (might be server lag?)
- To remove mouse acceleration completely you have to edit .ini files.
"
hoursPlayed: January 24, 2015

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game!  Fun to pick up and play, even for a casual game.  It's intense without being overbearing, as the absence of a calcified rank system removes the drive for the next level
date: all while maintaining competitiveness.  The flexibility of this game means a player can be a pro-grade die hard UT fan, a casual bloke (or blokette) who just wants to blow off some steam (get it?), or anywhere in between!  The devs actually listen to their customers, and this is a product that could easily be worth 3 times as much as it is.  Get it while it's hot!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a tough one. What I played, I really loved. However, that's at around 18-20 fps. I know it's not me, as I just got done playing Crysis 3 at a steady 60 fps with everything on 'high.' It may be because I have an AMD Radeon card. I'm not going to fault the game for this as it is Early Access and it just came out. I'm also getting a bug where the options menu hangs everytime I apply the option. I can keep selecting ''apply,' but it won't go away, forcing me to manually close the game.

The game plays fantastic. Currently only one map, but the game feels fantastic. I'll give it a cautious recommendation and hope that it gets updated very soon.

EDIT: The game seems to be locked at 17 fps for me. This is...odd. I get 30fps at the splash screens. Then, in the menu AND gameplay, it just stays at 17. Neither up or down. Huh.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1 Map, 2 Game Modes, 7 Weapons... That is current early access state of game.

Weapons (in short):
You start with single/3fire pistol. Then you have one LMG which is reasonably strong. One weird Flamethrower which is very strong at very short range.
And now the 4 killers: Bullcraft Shotgun/Falcon Sniper/Stingray Plasma/Cerberus Rocket Launcher.
- if you know how to use them... 1 shot one kill.
Weapons are plenty on currently only map available and easy to access.

Movement (in shorter):
- Jump, Double Jump, Dodge+Jump, Wall Jump/Dodge
- If you can, you are twice as fast than those who can't

Game Modes (in shortest): DM/TDM

To wrap it all:
- game is unforgiving, you are either capable to frag or bottom feeder (No Skill, no Kill. I call it fair play!)
(I saw it in many matches, people ranging from K:D of 0:8 to 10:1)

Should you get into this fast train?
- If you like how randomly weapons shoot in modern games, which makes great players miss and give bad random hits, then this is not for you.
But if you gun in CS1.6 with AK three people across entire map before they can even aim at you, then you have skill required to be competitive here. Welcome to Frag Fest.

Here you have feature list tracker (roadmap):
http://forum.toxikk.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=993

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best first person shooters I have played in years, if not the best period, which is quite surprising considering it isn't even done yet and I'm not normally a huge fan of early access games. Trust me, this game is worth it. If you like old school arena shooters at all, you will love Toxikk. Everything works exactly as it should within the parameters of the genre. The movement is extremely well-polished, the weapons feel natural (although some need balance adjustments as of the Wasabi build), and the atmostphere is perfect.

There's no f2p pay-2-win BS-- another reason to respect the developers. They refuse to put in the nickel and diming model of most AAA studios anymore. It's a breath of fresh air when someone is actually pro-consumer anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, So. I have been eagerly waiting for this game to be released since I saw the Debut Trailer back in August. I see that the game is released and quickly pick it up to see if it was going to live up to my hype over the past few months, and to be honest, I am not disappointed. The game is very smooth, the graphics are very well done, the movement is fliud, the guns are fun to use, neat character customization, leaderboards, gameplay is a load of fun, the list can go on for miles.

The only negatives I can even try to come up with right now is the slight gun balance issue, and the lack of more maps, which i'm sure will be dealt with soon as those aren't very big issues and its all a part of the game development.

This game also keeps the skill based gameplay from Quake and Unreal Tournament, yet still allows for anyone to enjoy this game, even against bots.

So a quick summary of the Pros and Cons of the game.

Pros
+ Very smooth game to run
+ Graphics are outstanding
+ Very fluid movement
+ Guns are enjoyable to use
+ Character customization
+ Leaderboards
+ Gameplay is addicting
+ No health regeneration
+ A reasonable price
+ No buying weapons or Leveling (You must find your weapons on the map)
+ Just a quality game in general

Cons
- Slight gun balance issue
- Limited map selection


Verdict

9/10

I have to give it a 9 out of 10, alongside the great gameplay and graphics, it also has a nostalgic feel to it due to playing Quake and Unreal Tournament for hours on end many years back. If you enjoy Arena shooters, or just shooters in general, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is so well made and well polished for both an early access game and an indie game.
The gameplay is amazing so far, like Quake but with new mechanics (like dashing & wall jumping) to keep it fresh.
The graphics are absolutely beautiful. There is so much detail put into every single texture, no corners were cut.
Even though there is only one map so far (wasabi build), it's so well designed, both graphically and gameplay-wise, that I wouldn't mind playing the same map all day (lol, for now at least)
The weapons feel very balanced; I don't know why the haters think the Cerberus is so OP, maybe it's because fighting against it requires SKILL (damn COD kids).
I can't wait till the next build, with the huge Rockies map and vehicles.

I guess I'm not leaving my basement anymore. I'll never regret this purchase.
BUY NOW GODDAMMIT

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very smooth, fast paced, highly polished, great graphics. This game is frantic and action packed. The bots are fantastic, and if you crank them up they'll offer a really good challenge. I've played this game solo and co-op with my buddy and we had a great time. The team deathmatch is fun, and then there's a capture the flag mode on a huge map with rivers, vehicles, mountains, and bridges. We had the bots turned up one notch above the middle and it took us quite a while to finally score. It actually ended up being a bot on our team that finally brought the flag home but we helped it get back to base.

Wow, what a blast! If you're looking for a great old-school action FPS with health, armor, and weapon pickups, vehicles, and bots so you can play solo or co-op, this is a great choice.
