reviewText:
Early Access Review

An appetizer for now, delicious supper later!

It has been sometime, I would say, since there has been a good FPS that is worth looking at for more then a glance. Toxikk seems to want to be a small niche shooter for those gamers who want to enjoy a arcade/arena shooter, it runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and plays quite well. The speed seems to feel faster and more intended compared to UT3 which is a blessing but as you can tell by any screenshot it feels very much alike in terms of design. Toxikk seems to copy the atmosphere of UT3 which can feel kinda wierd with how simple and clean arena shooters are meant to look, more of an opinion, but they certainly could have picked a more vibrant map to showcase the game with then the one in Hong Kong, which can feel very much like Shangri La off UT3.

Now the movement and fluidity of the game feels overall very good as it should be. I spend a few matches alone just dodging in and out of areas. And the guns used in our single map seem to work really damn well. The guns so far implemented are the...
Raven (Handgun with an alternate fire burst of 3-4 rounds EXTREAMLY like UT3),
Bullcraft (Shotgun with a great alternate fire with a pretty beefy blast radius somewhat feels like a flack cannon), Violator (Assult machine gun with a canon style launch alternate fire kinda like flack guns alternate),
Falcon (Simple sniper rifle with nice looks but wish it was a lightning gun),
Stingray (Acts like a much quicker link gun with a shock rifle type alternate fire),
Dragoneer (Flame through that does quite good in close quarters usually I would think these would suck in arena fps),
Cerberus (Rocket launcher, unfortunately doesn't fire more then one rocket with alternate).

Weapons seem pretty good so far and there alternate fire is very well done.

The developers might have a pretty good flushed out game on their hands that really has released at a good time. A lot of arena shooters are in development and the only big one thats open source is far from completion on the new UE4. reviewText:
Early Access Review

REVIEW WILL BE UPDATED AS GAME PROGRESSES

If you don't want to read a long review, then here's an easy choice:

If you LOVED UT2004 (or the Unreal Tournament series in general) and want to support/play a very early version of what could be a phenominal game buy it for the cheaper price now.

If you always preferred Quake over Unreal Tournament, or don't want to buy a unfinished game, don't puchase this.

It's as simple as that.


For a more IN DEPTH review, here are my thoughts so far.

-Pros

Fantastic movement system, you can set how fast your double taps dodge or even use another key entirely to dodge in the position you're moving, which is excellent for newer players (or baddies like me).

Weapons actually feel varied, and a lot actually adapt to team colors when picked up (like the stingray, instead of the traditional teal shots they will change to a darker blue for the blue team or a red for the red team) which is a nice touch.

Game looks fantastic, running on the Unreal 3 engine (sadly not 4, but I supposed it's been in development for a long time) and still looks great. Plenty of graphical settings to tweak, which is expected of a PC only game.

Is actually FUN to play, one of the most important aspects of a game period. It's entertaining and if you've loved Unreal Tournament you will most likely love this.

-Cons

It is early access. At the time of writing there is only one map, and two modes. Now has two maps and three modes, deathmatch, team deathmatch and CTF. Know what you're getting into and realize the possibility (not assuming anything, just stating it could happen) the devs abandon the game similar to other early access titles. Only buy this if you trust that the devs will deliver on their plans.

Balance is off right now, again it is early and this will most likely be sorted out, but it's worth noting that the cerberus is a one hit on fresh spawns and fires far too quickly, while the starting pistol is essentially worthless. While it's worth noting the starting pistol should be BAD, this is almost unusable. Game has been properly balanced, weapons all feel fair as of now.

Leveling system is, well, superfluous. It doesn't do anything at the moment, it's incredibly easy to level up (even bots give levels) and the numebers go rediculously high (I think I'm level 670 at the moment?). I don't understand why a system that is completely unneeded or unused is in the current build, but this is basically nitpicking since it doesn't do anything.


So overall, if you trust the devs to finish the game and want to play it now, it's definitely worth the $19 (on sale for $17 at time of writing). I'll try to keep this post updated, but honestly I'm a pretty forgetful person. Solid recommendation as of now.

EDIT: I will strike out any outdated info and add notes stating what changed.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An appetizer for now, delicious supper later!

It has been sometime, I would say, since there has been a good FPS that is worth looking at for more then a glance. Toxikk seems to want to be a small niche shooter for those gamers who want to enjoy a arcade/arena shooter, it runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and plays quite well. The speed seems to feel faster and more intended compared to UT3 which is a blessing but as you can tell by any screenshot it feels very much alike in terms of design. Toxikk seems to copy the atmosphere of UT3 which can feel kinda wierd with how simple and clean arena shooters are meant to look, more of an opinion, but they certainly could have picked a more vibrant map to showcase the game with then the one in Hong Kong, which can feel very much like Shangri La off UT3.

Now the movement and fluidity of the game feels overall very good as it should be. I spend a few matches alone just dodging in and out of areas. And the guns used in our single map seem to work really damn well. The guns so far implemented are the...
Raven (Handgun with an alternate fire burst of 3-4 rounds EXTREAMLY like UT3),
Bullcraft (Shotgun with a great alternate fire with a pretty beefy blast radius somewhat feels like a flack cannon), Violator (Assult machine gun with a canon style launch alternate fire kinda like flack guns alternate),
Falcon (Simple sniper rifle with nice looks but wish it was a lightning gun),
Stingray (Acts like a much quicker link gun with a shock rifle type alternate fire),
Dragoneer (Flame through that does quite good in close quarters usually I would think these would suck in arena fps),
Cerberus (Rocket launcher, unfortunately doesn't fire more then one rocket with alternate).

Weapons seem pretty good so far and there alternate fire is very well done.

The developers might have a pretty good flushed out game on their hands that really has released at a good time. A lot of arena shooters are in development and the only big one thats open source is far from completion on the new UE4. If players continue to recieve weekly or biweekly updates on maps and they are flushed out and don't feel sammy there will be great success. Keep doin what you're doin devs. I hope to see that one map in the preview with snow and a mountain/lake soon! Show us players other gametypes that we could put those weapons to use with, looks good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**EARLY ACCESS REVIEW**

----------------------------
>EARLY ACCESS DETAILS<

Be warned that the game contains for now only one playable maps, with only DM and TDM modes and no mutators. HOWEVER, additional content should come in pretty quickly since a lot of the content shown in the trailer is not there yet, meaning it's probably almost ready to be added to the official build. On top of that, the core gameplay is 99% done I think, the 1% left being the details they MIGHT change according to user feedback, so IF I'm right and the core gameplay is mostly done, that means the focus will be on adding content to the game (even maybe additional gameplay).

>EARLY ACCESS DETAILS<
----------------------------

OMG. That's what I think of this game. I never felt such a tension since I played UT2k4. Actually the whole game is a love letter to UT2k4 with modern graphics and a whole new set of weapons (it still have classics projectile but powerful weapons, explosive-type weapons, widespread weapons and charged weapons but there is many fun and new primaryand secondary fire modes. Cause yeah, the game features two fire modes, something introduced by the Unreal serie and used almost nowhere else (unfortunately IMHO) and here it goes.

It's exactly what I excpected from UT3, an evolution of UT2k4, with better graphics, a few twist of its own, and a competitive gameplay.

In short there are now 2 main competitors" that aren't really in competition. Reflex and Toxikk. BUt as I said they do not compete
recommended: is UT-like arena shooter where Reflex is a lot more akin to Quake ;) Still you should own both at some point (wait a bit for Reflex it's not that much polished as of now).\n\nLast but not least

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though I've played only a little bit in this game, I can tell by the mechanics and gameplay to say this is a great game. It's as the trailer says: no reloading, no cover system, no classes.

My first geniune FPS I've ever played was Goldeneye 007 for the N64. The game is a classic and didn't have so many FPS standards we're so used to today. TOXIKK manages to bring the FPS genre back to basics, gameplay found more typical in '90s shooters a la Unreal Tournament and Doom, but in a way that's refreshing and just purely fun for this current decade.

My only gripe is that no one seems to play online compared to other FPS games. I might recommend making this game free-to-play to bring in more players, but that could cheapen the quality of this game. I'm hoping with the recent release of DOOM that arena shooters such as TOXIKK get more popular.

Overall, this game is quite good for Early Access and I'm quite excited to see where the game goes from here.

It is a competent arena style shooter with amazing graphics, a variety of weapons with two different fire modes each and is generally just entertaining. The downside, as many people have already stated is the playerbase. I for one can play a round with bots once in a while and get enjoyment out of it, but for a multiplayer centric game it is pretty much lacking the most basic ressource: active players. It is sad and certainally not the games fault but this is just a too important negative factor to recommend this game in general. If you don't care too much about that sinceyou want to play it with a group of friends or just bots, pick it up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you love UT99 / 2004 (and 3 of course :-)) .... you'll love this one.

This early access version actually feels like a final game. It is highly polished, the gameplay works almost flawless.
I'm just as much hyped as I've been when UT2003 came out. Toxikk is a bomb of a game.
Today, the newest update has been released, featuring the vehicular mode capture the cell (basically vCTF but with little interesting twists!) and a new map.
So far the beta only has two maps but I've been playing them for nearly 20hours total. Roughly 15hours on just the first map..
The game is highly addicting and fun. That is not only my opinion but the opinion of dozens of players in the game chat. The players are friendly and fair (so far). I could not find any harassment yet. I could always find a server with players. Even though it's just a test version with (as of writing this) 2 maps.
Oh did I mention the graphics look gorgeous.........?

I really love what Reakktor Studios have done with this. In my opinion it sets the newest milestone for arena fps!
With more maps coming, this game will beat everything comparable out there, hands down. I don't even care about the newest UT in the making since they don't even seem to know what they're doing and Toxikk already sets the bar really high!

Skill wins here, no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t luck with unlocked perks and upgrades...
If you want to compete your skill. Play Toxikk.

Frag like it's 1999

reviewText:
Early Access Review

These two posts summarize my feelings on this game:

Originally posted by rocKit:In general, the entire discussion about why the game lacks of people playing it, is kinda barren, and misses one important factor -- the devs. Yes, the pricetag -- taking into consideration the fact that UT4 for example is totally free to play -- can pull away a certain number of players. But the major issue is the developers' incomprehensible behavior.

My biggest concern relates to the maps. I purchased the game in March this year and since that time they managed to release just a SINGLE deathmatch map (Ganesha) - which was in fact using the same props and assests like one of the previous two (Artifact). I don't count the VCTF maps (as far as i know there are two of them), because I can't recall that fragging in 1999 was involving vehicles - so yes, I don't give a damn for this mode. Why on Earth haven't they provide a blockout" state or "shell" maps (like Reflex or UT4 did)? If not why haven't they released the map editor for the game? The community would fill the gap quickly enough and that could bring back the community to a certain degree! Instead
date: they're pulling the wool over our eyes with the pompously announced reskin of UT2k4 Deck17 - something that would be done long enough
recommended: if the map editor was released. And btw
hoursPlayed:
it's been nearly month and a half since that announcement -- where the hell is the "DEKK"? Is the game still about to be release on 22nd of January 2016? Because with the current pace it's not going to come out in January 2017...

And don't try to sugar-coat it with the Early Access mantra. It's as early as it was 7 months ago and it's not getting more complete in anyway. And since I've paid a full price for it I do have a right complain.

I have a hope that the developers behavior can be explained by a sheer incompetence... But the slow pace of development arouses my suspicions that there might be something much more ominous going on behind the scenes. So far
voteText: Toxikk is my biggest disappointment of 2015.\nOriginally posted by MeowMeowFuzzyface:Originally posted by rocKit:And don't try to sugar-coat it with the Early Access mantra. It's as early as it was 7 months ago and it's not getting more complete in anyway.This is what happens when the devs have your money already.  I bought Toxikk to support people still developing AFPS games
helpfulPercent: but now I'm starting to have doubts.  They were promising the SDK when I bought the game in June and 5 months later I haven't seen any indication of it actually coming.  In that time I saw one new map and some minor netcode and balance patches.  The game has stagnated because they take ages to release maps.  I don't blame anyone for getting bored after playing the same maps over and over again.\n\nI think the devs did an amazing job up until v0.8 or so.  They said they are putting some things into the final version that they can't reveal
votesHelpful: and that's the reason for such slow development.  We will see.\n\nFor now
votesTotal: I've uninstalled the game.  There's no one playing
votesFunny: there's no patches
commentsCount: there's no new maps
column16: and there's no SDK.  Even on the few Friday frag fests that I was able to attend
column17: we had 3 or 4 players max.\n\nI really hope they have something in the works that will justify the slow progress.  I have no way of knowing their budget
column18: but I can't imagine it's enough to keep development going for another full year.  I still praise the quality of the game and the competent development
column19: but I'm starting to feel like it was a poor decision to purchase it at this point.\n\nAs to your suspicions about the developers
column20: I don't think they're bad people.  The quality of the game tells me that they were genuine about their project.  That being said
column21: I suspect development did slow down after they got so many backers and early access buyers.  Does it make sense to keep putting all your money into developing a game after it has sold already?  We've put our faith into them by buying the alpha
column22: so now let's see if this developer can deliver on their promises.  In retrospect
column23: I do think they've made a few poor choices
column24: but there's nothing that makes me think they're disingenuous (yet)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fast paced annihilation, a modern revamp of arena shooters of old. Refreshing to see such a well-made fps from a small but well established studio. Fantastic game but really needing help from the community to grow its player base. Right now there is not enough players to play Multiplayer but bots are still extremely fun, especially if you set up a server and you and your friends play together. Great graphics, well balanced, awesome fun, and a great job overall.

I recommend this if you have friends that are willing to buy this and play with you. Otherwise wait until the community grows.

91/100

reviewText:
Early Access Review

These two posts summarize my feelings on this game:

Originally posted by rocKit:In general, the entire discussion about why the game lacks of people playing it, is kinda barren, and misses one important factor -- the devs. Yes, the pricetag -- taking into consideration the fact that UT4 for example is totally free to play -- can pull away a certain number of players. But the major issue is the developers' incomprehensible behavior.

My biggest concern relates to the maps. I purchased the game in March this year and since that time they managed to release just a SINGLE deathmatch map (Ganesha) - which was in fact using the same props and assests like one of the previous two (Artifact). I don't count the VCTF maps (as far as i know there are two of them), because I can't recall that fragging in 1999 was involving vehicles - so yes, I don't give a damn for this mode. Why on Earth haven't they provide a blockout" state or "shell" maps (like Reflex or UT4 did)? If not why haven't they released the map editor for the game? The community would fill the gap quickly enough and that could bring back the community to a certain degree! Instead
date: they're pulling the wool over our eyes with the pompously announced reskin of UT2k4 Deck17 - something that would be done long enough
recommended: if the map editor was released. And btw
hoursPlayed:
it's been nearly month and a half since that announcement -- where the hell is the "DEKK"? Is the game still about to be release on 22nd of January 2016? Because with the current pace it's not going to come out in January 2017...

And don't try to sugar-coat it with the Early Access mantra. It's as early as it was 7 months ago and it's not getting more complete in anyway. And since I've paid a full price for it I do have a right complain.

I have a hope that the developers behavior can be explained by a sheer incompetence... But the slow pace of development arouses my suspicions that there might be something much more ominous going on behind the scenes. So far
voteText: Toxikk is my biggest disappointment of 2015.\nOriginally posted by MeowMeowFuzzyface:Originally posted by rocKit:And don't try to sugar-coat it with the Early Access mantra. It's as early as it was 7 months ago and it's not getting more complete in anyway.This is what happens when the devs have your money already.  I bought Toxikk to support people still developing AFPS games
helpfulPercent: but now I'm starting to have doubts.  They were promising the SDK when I bought the game in June and 5 months later I haven't seen any indication of it actually coming.  In that time I saw one new map and some minor netcode and balance patches.  The game has stagnated because they take ages to release maps.  I don't blame anyone for getting bored after playing the same maps over and over again.\n\nI think the devs did an amazing job up until v0.8 or so.  They said they are putting some things into the final version that they can't reveal
votesHelpful: and that's the reason for such slow development.  We will see.\n\nFor now

column18: but I can't imagine it's enough to keep development going for another full year.  I still praise the quality of the game and the competent development

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is freakin' awesome. Imagine Unreal Tournament 2004 with modern graphics.

Too bad it has no players.

And by no players I mean literally ZERO players. The servers are a ghost town.

For that reason I cannot recommend this game unless you feel like playing bots or you're going to LAN with your friends.

Honestly, the developers should pull the game off Steam in its current state and re-launch once they have more content and they're prepared for a massive marketing campaign.

I hope the full release of this game comes with a good marketing campaign because I'd love this game to do well.

I will update this review once the game comes out of early access.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\ntoxik doesn't look quite as good to me as unreal tournament 3 and it doesn't play nearly as well either. it looks okay a glance but the trade-off's they have made here for performance are mostly in the textures and there isn't any of the fancy stuff that makes modern games look superior to ur3. let's face it, you can only do so much to make ur3 look good amongst games on the newer engines but i think we've seen ur3 engine games that look better than this although most of them aren't twitch arena shooters. nexuiz, which is on cryengine, performs and looks much better than toxik and it plays better and it appears that nexuiz are about to make a comeback on steam. nexuiz might be a better option for this gameplay style if they start selling it again. but none of these indies are going to touch unreal tournament 4 in terms of graphics and gameplay. if you're going to play a game like toxik, you may as well be playing ut 3 because the ai are superior and toxik's player base probably isn't much bigger than ut3's. the ai in toxik ranges from unstoppable to bumping into the walls but there is really isn't much in between and that's on the average" difficulty setting. also

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is the new breed of arena shooter.  It has a feel very similiar to the old Unreal Tournament games, that's for sure.  Sound-wise the game is satisfying and well done - a step up from the old breeds.  Graphics-wise the game is gorgeous but there are some textures errors here and there, but nothing really noticible (you have to look to see them, and it could have been on my end).  The controls are tight, responsive and well produced.  The guns seem to be balanced and offer a good variety of strategy and tactics in order to master the elements for success in this game.  However, despite all the goodness in the deathmatch mode, the capture modes are weak and not fun - the maps are too big and feel lacking in the arena feel.  Overall the deathmatch maps at this point are great, fun, well designed, and balanced.  They are gorgeous as well and feature wonderful and engaging sounds/music.  The team play capture maps, I personally think, are lacking, not fun, and battles are too spread apart.  So far at this stage in the early release there are always good US servers to play on.  Netcode seems to be tight and responsive.  If you are an arena fan, get this game.  Also the developers are responding to the community very well, and very quickly.  Great Devs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really don't want to give Toxikk a bad review. The game itself is a ton of fun, don't get me wrong. Despite what my playtime implies, I haven't had this much fun with a multiplayer shooter in a long time. The problem is that the playerbase is super low. I thought it might have just been a dead time of day, but take a look at the game's activity charts. There's very few people playing this game, and that's a very bad thing for a game meant to be multiplayer-only. I didn't buy a multiplayer-only game just for botmatches.

Maybe this game will get popular once it leaves early access, who knows. But for now, it's not worth it...it's a whole lot of fun, but there's nobody to play with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's no UT2k4

I understand they wanted fast no-bs gunplay, but this is ridiculous. Seriously. Hitboxes are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, maps claustrophobic in a way that UT never was, and movement so ludicrously fast landing any sort of blow is 90% luck.

Not only that. Armor and health pickups do next to nothing, since pretty much every gun does a stupid amount of damage.

It's a shame, because the larger map really is a lot of fun. But the core combat is so dodge based, it's almost as if they forgot about the whole Shooter" part. Vehicles are balanced really well

TO DEVELOPERS,
SHORT STORY, 4 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• OUT OF 8 =  FOUR ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ON A TATE.

LONG STORY:

please, I urge you to head my advice, never either; make pc only games, make pay to play pc games with microtransactions, make old genration remakes in a modern fps fashion with no one to play with and lastly, make a game and only use steam greenligt as an 'ad' if you can even call grrenlight an ad host.

The pros:
game's solid, good for my specs and lower to quite a degree.
fun bots, only i can't tell if they are good ai or not its hektic to play
no reload, i flipping love this for no realod!

cons:
lacks developer love, yes you read this correctly fellas the devs (and im sorry to say) even with the short time i played and regardless of it being early access, there is no excuse for the lack of content in this game, the low demand for a game such as this one is detremental to the devs unless they stand out. they didn't. as soon as i got on i went it was blurry, too much contrast, too light/ dark at times the ai was choppy and just lacked generic attention to detail.

no one is playing. nuff said no ads to support you and no reason not to make one, you have the budget.

even if i could play online regularly, its boring and bots are silly if this game doesn't have a campaign hear me out M'k?
this game is not baad because the bots are not content driven, i am a player who if i can't play online, I would want some story here and there, maybe a quest of some sort or just level based stuff, MAYBE even back story for god's sake as to why this game is blue v red (TF2) and why this game is doesn't have a wave mode

I know the devs won't listen or might not even look at my comment but devs, i aint got anything against you its just the guy i am and the things i play and the way i want to play them just don't fit with another shooter based on online capabilities. if this game was f2p gr8 but you stated no plans for that as you don't want many microtransactions i get thet but there isn't a need to charge 19.99 dollars for a game not worth 5 and there is no denial

I WILL ADMIT IT IS GORGEOUS THOUGH BUT NOT ENOUGH TO SEE OR DO OTHER THAN COLLECT GUNS, KILL OR BE KILLED, RESPAWN WITH A PISTOL AND SAW, RINSE REPEAT

long story at an end devs you know what you need to do i really wanna play this game but at its current state its almost impossible for me, boring and tedious. tf2 is not that much different other than map events and jump pads thats about it. Literally.

well guys have a good one

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tryhards will clear the ONLY server with people by going 30:1. Be prepared for their testosterone-fulled indiscretion and lack of foresight. It's hard to beta test when you don't have fun AND have to pay for it. Thankfully there are good people around if you keep poking about; don't turn down a server because they are using custom content or show 160 ping.

That being said, the game itself is largely solid. It handles high ping well. I really enjoy the Bullcraft and Dragoneer. Rockets and AR 'nades are one-shots, though, hope that gets patched out. Maps are decent, though very tight and random (need a few more, specifically orderly and/or spacious ones like Dekk and Ganesha IMO). Dekk looks fantastic, whoever worked on remodeling that map needs a bonus and to be told to make a novel map.

I am marking not recommended (for most) because early access + diehard tryhards clearing the only server or two = rough. Will re-review on launch.

Early Access Review

EDIT - No longer reccomending game: Not many people are playing anymore and there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of effort being put into the game, make sure you know what you're getting into if you buy this game.

EDIT - [No particular version]: Linux support pls. Before stuff gets too big and crazy I hope devs will make versions for other operating systems.

EDIT - CURY: The game now has a second map for CTF and has 2 vehicles. It is still lacking content enough content for me to feel confident in recommending it to my friends but that's why it's in early access. This game still shows quite some promise IMO.

This is great but ITS NOT FOR EVERYONE. If you have never played an arena FPS or like arena FPSes then you will (probably) love Toxikk. If you hate them, the experience is no different. I personally have never played an arena FPS and I love this game. I originally found this game on kickstarter a couple years ago and thought it looked amazing but unfortunately I could not support the campaign at the time, here we are now, this game is great, I am in love with the concept BUT it has only one map at the moment (I'm writing this review 2 days after it was released on early access so thats probably changed by the time you're reding this). If you like the concept I strongly recommend picking this game up for only $17 but if you're looking for an extensive FPS this is not it... yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What I think of Toxikk  A continued update

This game looks great. It has great visual details to it, sparks, explosions, laser pew pew pews, but I think that's where it stops being a good game.

Let's start with the pros, shall we?:

Pros:
Polished Beta
Visually amazing
Classic UT competitive feel
Shows a lot of promise
Description of Pros

What a great game to first start up and get into. The color choices, graphical additions (explosions, etc), and yes, even down to what they let you set in the settings, this game has it going on. With the vehicle additions, bigger maps, and other promises, I can see this game going far. I'd love to experience all of that in the final expansions to this game's beta and final release. For now, we can expect the devs to slowly roll out what they have to add.

Cons:
Terrible map design on this first map
The worst starting pistol ever designed
Sluggish character movement and terrible shift key (It's a mix of a jump run).
Starting settings are terrible
Unfair weapon choices (Rocket launcher dependent)
Gameplay seems sacrificed in order to maintain a sense of hardcore".
Gun pick ups take too long?
Description of Cons

Now... Where to begin... Let's start with the horrid map design. I don't know who was in charge of this beauty
date: but they need to check their work again. The map design feels like a mix of Call of Duty meets Operation Metro from BF4. Extremely tight corners
recommended: tunnels leadiing to MAYBE 1 or 2 exits

I don't think this pistol should be in the game due to the fact that when everyone has the laser rifle or rocket launcher

Excelent game I have enjoyed it for the most part.

But I can not give it a thumbs up because of the lack of organization on their end. (let me explain)

I Pre-ordered the 4 pack with a DLC code, I recieved my 4 game codes once the game came out in an email i used the first code and have enjoyed the game from that point on, but then next day my email cleaned out all my unmarked emails. The 3 extra codes are gond, now thats not their fault my email deleted all my unmarked emails on schedule. But in good faith I susspected Reakktor Studios to have a database containing all the users who ordered the games and the keys they recieved, I contacted the support team and recieved an email telling me that they could not help me because they do not store that information.

And about that DLC code, I was sopose to recieve another email at the beginning of February with it but still have yet to recieve that email or help from the support team

All in all it is a great game just be sure you put those keys somewhere safe!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Come on, if you're going to make a knockoff, don't build it on top of Unreal Tournament 3.  TOXIKK would be highly playable if it wasn't UT3 visually.  But, unfortunately, it is.

Pros:

-UT2004 movement.  Not everyone's cup of tea, but definitely mine.  You got your double jumps, wall jumps, slope jumps, jumps and potatoes, jump stew, jump gumbo, etc.  I was operating on UT2004 movement instinct and it translated almost perfectly to this game.

-You can press F to feign death and go ragdoll.  Possibly the most entertaining feature in UT3, and the fact that it's in this game is probably only a byproduct of the game being built on the UT3 UDK demo or something.


Cons:

-Everything else.

-Lack of visual clarity. It suffers from the same lack of visual clarity that made UT3 so fugly.  It's so cluttered and the lighting is way over-the-top, like in UT3.  I can't tell if I'm playing a shooter or attending a rave, with all of the flashy effects and glowing and bloom going on.

-Generic weaponry. It seems like 70% of them are hitscan weaponry that you feel like you just don't have enough room to use in the cramped single little deathmatch map they have.  I'm sure they'll release more deathmatch maps as time goes on, since this is early access, but for now, it's a problem.  They also lack personality, both visually and in function.

-Less of a fresh take on shooters that implements what made old shooters so fun and more of something that takes the physics and movement from UT2004 and puts it in a UT3 knockoff.



TL;DR Review: Go play UT3 instead, if you're craving a visually muddy shooter that you can press a button to ragdoll your character in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to like this game.  I wanted it to be a throwback to the arena shooters of old.

But it isn't.

In the arena shooters of old, you were spawned in a place where you could pickup a weapon, and move into the areas where your targets were.  And start fragging.

That doesn't happen in Toxikk.  In Toxikk, the spawns are random, so you might get spawned in the middle of the other team, and if you get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed over in a 1v4, too bad.  Even in a 1v1, you can spawn next to the guy that just killed you, and he could have the prime weapom (the Cerberus), higher health and armour.  You will get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• just as fast based on RNG.  Free kills for the other team, based on terribe spawning.

And if you get a lucky random spawn and start elsewhere?  Chances are, you wont get a weapon, because each weapon pickup has a 15 sec CD on it (the RL has a 30 sec now, because the devs don't understand weapon balance and didn't want to nerf it too hard).  So instead of a fluid game, you have to wait for a CD to finish to get a weapon.  And hope another player doesn't turn up and one shot you while you are waiting.

And with that being said, every weapon in the game has the potential to one shot you.  The usual ones apply, for example, the sniper rifle, that will kill you in one (head) shot.  But every weapon can do the same.  The Stingray alt fire works like the shock rifle, but it can headshot as well (‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•).  The flamethrower, can be charged up (much like the UT3 bio), but instead of having to lead and time it right, it can be unleashed (it is a fast forward firing projectile that kills anything in its path) to melt anyone instantly.  And the shotgun?  The alt fire is a double barrel, and it will kill you instantly.  It is fun to use, but boring to play against.  All of the weapons combine to make the game dull, because it is simply a case of point and click, instead of dodge and dominate.

Despite the bold claims of this game being a throwback to the 90s, this game is more of a 'we want CoD players!'.  Most of the weapons are based around one shot mechanics, which isn't such a bad thing, the game is very fast paced.  But the 2 seconds after spawning where you can't do ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• all (pistol cocking animation), coupled with the rubbish spawning and the weapon cooldowns, means you can get multiple kills in a row (every dead player leaves a +20 health pack, simple to survive no?), but once you die, you are so screwed, as you can die 5-6 times afterwards before you get a safe spawn and a weapon.

This game is great when the RNG suits you, you spawn on the best weapon and get to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, but when you die, no matter how good your skills are, you might end up a sitting duck when you spawn, with a guy just waiting for your 2 secs of spawn protection to end (you can't hit back during this) at which point, he gets a very free kill.

This game might turn out to be okay, but given how bad the weapon balance was on launch, and how bad the devs responded with their first patch, I would say to anyone, wait until this game is finished before you spend money on it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update: 4 months later the game has changed a bit and there are a few more maps. However, the chart linked below continues to show that there is really no interest in this game making it a bad buy at this point.

Original Review Jan 2015: If you like UT3, you will like this game. Literally the only difference between them is the weapons and the dodge jump. Toxikk is a repackage of the UT demo contained in UDK with only minor gameplay related changes and minor modifications to several models. There is nothing wrong with this, but if you think Toxikk is a polished game you should be impressed by what you can do with almost bone stock UDK content with a very small team.

If I had to guess, most of the time working on this game was spent on the menus and the leaderboard system. None of this means that the game is bad, but the only map available right now is very cramped, the weapons are not well balanced and the rocket launcher is overpowered to all heck. You can easily dominate a match by focusing on the rockets and timing the armor. But despite all that you can actually have fun with this game and if you want some of the feeling of UT3 mixed with a small amount of UT2004 you will probably enjoy what this game has to offer.

FYI, F is feign death and Q is turn invisible (yes everyone can turn invisible)

In the end I'm voting No" on recommending this simply because the game is incomplete. The one map gets boring fast and if you aren't used to arena FPSes
date: you will die more than you will kill which is frustrating. Give this a bit more time in the fryer and it will be a decent game.\n\nP.S. Thanks trolls for down-voting an honest review. This chart http://steamcharts.com/app/324810 tells you all you need to know about whether it's worth buying this game right now."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game still has a long way to go, but it does show signs of promise. While the graphics engine & gameplay is smooth there is currently very little to it.

Simply put:
- There is only 1 map.
- The game mimicks Unreal Tournament gameplay.
- Configuring the mouse sensitivity is a bit frustrating - you cannot configure options in-game.

This is an early access game... and just like many others currently on Steam I urge you to wait for the game to properly release before buying into it.

This game shows promise and you can tell that the creators have had a lot of help from the UT format of gameplay. Keep an eye on this one, it is fluid and graphically pleasing, but in no way ready for the public.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although technically still in alpha, this game doesn't do anything for the genre in its current form. It's essentially an Unreal Tournament 2004 clone with prettier graphics. The current map is also typical of an UT deathmatch map, featuring tight areas and some sense of vertical height. The map itself is well designed as are the weapon models and the sound effects have quite a bit of impact. Expect powerups such as health vials and armour to be placed strategically, the same strategies of Quake also apply here. Variety of weapons is limited; as you'd expect for a game this early in development but each handles well and are overall quite balanced with the exception of the shotgun and rocket launcher. Most of the weapons are also too similar to those found in UT 2004; to the point where they even share the exact same secondary fire modes.

I'm hopeful for the future of this game but in reality, quite worried that it will play it too safe and not deviate from the already established formula.

In my opinion, it will take some creative map design and new game modes to separate this game from UT. As an example, there are a lot of things which can be learned from Halo 4 which we've not yet seen on PC. It would be interesting to merge the exotic map design and experimental game modes of H4 with a fast paced old-school competitive shooter like Toxikk. Even the free-to-play Tribes: Ascend was built off being able to predict player movement and splash damage whilst travelling at fast speeds. It would be extremely refreshing and beneficial to this genre to introduce more platformer type mechanics into deathmatch maps.

I hope the developers don't stick to the same design philosophies for other game modes and hope they really try and craft something special.

Early Access Review

I thought this was going to feel like UT (any of them) but was sorely disappointed. The store screenshots and video had vehicles and many more environments. Right now it's just one map that's very cramped. It really doesn't feel like it's worth even five dollars where it stands right now. You move too slow, rocket launcher is really the only viable weapon, all the guns sound like muffled cap guns, mouse acceleration is on by default, MOTION BLUR (really?), and a whole bunch of other issues.

I grew up on UT99 and can tell you that I can grab the CD for UT99, install it, and have more fun right now that what this game provides. The community is pretty offputting too with massive downvotes for anyone who criticizes it. Hopefully it gets better in the future, but right now it's not worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is exactly what it looks like and what they say it is. if you're looking for an ultra-fast-paced, old-school shooter, get it.

Also, these devs understand Early Access better than most. Rather than release a 0.0001 and expect people to bear with them for an eternal alpha, they have a beta whose biggest changes are balance-related. There is currently only one map available not because they decided to build 10% of a product and ship it as is, but because they want to make sure the weapons are balanced with as few variables as possible before they turn on another slew of already-created, yet-to-be-100%-polished content. They currently plan to have the next massive wave of content released around February 12, following the last of the major weapon balance tweaks.

Great gameplay, great performance (!), great devs! Can't wait for more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Is this game good? Yes it is. What we have here is exactly as advertised: a skill based, fast shooter that is an ode to the days of quake and unreal.

But if you are reading this review during the early access, you may wish to wait a while. The game in its current state as I write this is much like an early alpha purely for testing purposes. Fun? Yes. But there are the expected flaws that come with such an early build. Only one map and one gamemode is currently working/available. Weapons are not balanced, a few bugs here and there, and server connection issues abound. If you decide to buy into the e-a just know that you are getting into an incomplete game. It will probably be months before enough content is playable for this to be considered something for legitimate retail.

Beyond that the core gameplay is excellent, movement is fun, and it's been ages since we have had a shooter like this. Reakktor Studios at the very least desrves props for trying to bring twitch and skill back to a the FPS genre, which has stagnated heavily from casual pandering military shooters for the past decade. In exchange for more realism shooters lost a part of their soul, and Toxikk is trying to bring it back. Give it a chance.

This game brings back the fun in online shooters that went missing in action long ago.

Seriously get the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Toxikk reminds me of all the good things about playing Quake 3 or Unreal Tournament back in the late 90s.

Imagine that gameplay, but with today's graphics.  The developers have got amazing results using the Unreal Engine.  The game looks gorgeous on Ultra settings with a solid 60FPS.  You really feel like you're fighting in the alleys of a futuristic city.   Weapons are well varied and tight and the mix of them make fighting in the city map quite frenetic.

The netcode seems to be working alright, I didn't notice any bad lag when playing multiplayer.  There are also single player missions to help ease you back into your happy fragging place.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before I begin, Id like to preface this by saying that this is a first impression of Alpha gameplay, and subject to change.

I'm very excited for this game, and the potential it holds. Its a very pretty, pretty game: the lighting and colors are beautiful. The audio is on point, the music just loud enough to hear, but not loud enough to cover whats going on. I enjoy the design style, and i personally quite like the double jump and dodge maneuvers implemented in the gameplay.

I have two issues with the game.

Firstly, I expected more. The trailer had multiple maps, while the release on has one, and a small one at that. As well, I got turned around quite a bit, and I still have trouble locating one of the weapons consistently. The trailer also promised vehicles, of which there are none, and 9 weapons, of which I can count 5 or 6. I understand that this is an Alpha release, but Im just somewhat dissapointed.

My other issue is with one of the weapons, the Cerberus launcher. To me, it seems like it is too overpowered, or at least, overused. I personally prefer the Violator, especially its grenade launcher. While playing with bots, all of them use the Cerberus to the point of ridiculousness, and the actual servers provided me with too much lag to get a proper approximation of what they were like.

All of these issues can, and I hope will be, fixed by later patches of the game, and I am excited to see what the future holds for this game.

UPDATE:
I must say, after playing another match or two, my opinion of the game has vastly improved, on top of my already high opinion. My new favorite weapon, the Stingray, is immensly satisfying to kill with, especially with its secondary fire. I would also like to amend my previous statement about the Cerberus, as now that Ive figured out how to dodge, I can avoid the rockets for the most part and retaliate with the Stingray before they can get off a second shot.

Im a little dissapointed that this map doesnt allow us to use the Falcon very much, as its scoped zoom is almost useless in this close quarters map. As well, i would still have liked to see a couple more weapons, but perhaps on a larger map, as another weapon would make this one feel too cluttered.

While playing Squad mode, I quite enjoyed the little markers that would tell you where your teamates recently died, as it made it easier to find the nests of enemies the bots inevitably formed.

I still have some concerns.
Firstly, the fact that you cannot change settings or options while in game is incredibly frustrating, and lead to me having to quit matches to change my graphics settings far too many times. As well, the framrerate can tank, which is annoying to say the least.

Also, the lack of weapon names in the controls while changing keybindings frustrated me. Perhaps because of my years playing Quake, I expected to be able to see which weapon is which, so I could map them to keys accordingly, but sadly, this was not the case.

I shall update this review as my experience continues.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI always dine upon the reviews of my fellow steamonians but have never brought a dish of my own to the feast. This game changed all that. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is exactly what it looks like and what they say it is. if you're looking for an ultra-fast-paced, old-school shooter, get it.

Also, these devs understand Early Access better than most. Rather than release a 0.0001 and expect people to bear with them for an eternal alpha, they have a beta whose biggest changes are balance-related. There is currently only one map available not because they decided to build 10% of a product and ship it as is, but because they want to make sure the weapons are balanced with as few variables as possible before they turn on another slew of already-created, yet-to-be-100%-polished content. They currently plan to have the next massive wave of content released around February 12, following the last of the major weapon balance tweaks.

Great gameplay, great performance (!), great devs! Can't wait for more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although this game is still in beta, it makes AAA title Betas look like abandoned projects. The weapon system was slightly unbalanced at first, but after they changed up weapon strengths/spawn times, it has become much more enjoyable. I prefer base loadouts for all players in a FPS; it keeps the playing field level. But when a game allows you to hoard weapons, it can be very frustrating to players trying to find a gun that will stand a chance. This game does not have that problem.
Everything about this title so far has delivered. It is a no-nonsense fast paced old school shooter with a new age feel. There are no perks or classes. The only thing that determines the win is skill, and a little luck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will judge this game ttaking some things into consideration.  1)  This is a BETA and as such is incomplete  2)  related to Beta status, there is one map and 2 game types right now.

So, if you are a COD/BF fan looking for your next game, please keep on looking, im sure the next rehash of those games will come soon.  This is not a game based off of modern combat and using iron sights, this is a twitch game.  If you loved Q2/3 and UT99, this is the game for you.  Not saying it is perfect, and I doubt anything will fully replace UT99 or Q3 for me, but this is, FROM WHAT IS RELEASED RIGHT NOW, a game worthy of carrying the torch for those.

The game is fast and frantic, fun weapons, starter wep blows, badly, Makes me with for the cheesey machinegun form Q3 or the Enforcer., also I think the Dragoneer blocks vision a bit too much, but overall, from what is complete I have no major complaints.

I am looking forward to more game types coming, as well as the option of starting private servers and that we can contribute content, just like the old days of UT.  Graphics are good, not the best, but good, also while SLI is stablke, it is not utilizing the other card(s), which isn't a huge deal, but I would like to see this detail added/corrected as time goes on.  There are some functions that need a bit of clarification as well, btu I think that will come with time as well.

Right now, I am looking forward to some more game time and having some old twitchy fun.

Today I give this a 7/10, and likely this will go up as the game matures and gets closer to complete.

Early Access Review

Although Toxikk is early access, and doesn't have much to offer at the moment, it promises hours of good fun, and if the devs stay true to what they have promised, I can promise you that Toxikk will be a game that you can't ignore.

Toxikk strives to stray from the other modern shooters, in fact, it seeks to bring back the Arena style gameplay from the late 90's and early 2k's by eliminating the reloading system, the health regaining, and the levelling systems. Now, being an arena shooter, it is extremely fast paced, from the movement to the short, yet brilliant encounters with your foes. forcing you to FRAG LIKE IT'S 1999".

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are moments playing Toxikk in its current state where you dont feel completely in control, for example when you spawn into a match there's a pistol reload animation that cant be interrupted, even if an enemy player is coming around the corner with buth barrels blazing. Its a small thing that presents a big problem, it makes you totally vulnerable at the exact point the player should be ready to lock and load. There are two ways they could solve this, one, make the player invulnerable for a few seconds after spawn, or two, get rid of the animation altogether. Personally i'd stump for the second option and it's something I really hope the developers address considering it puts a dent in the experience.

See video for my full impressions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CTkr1hU4Ceo

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I backed this a long time ago even though I'm not the best FPS player in the world.

This is how the bar should be set for Early Acess and Greenlight.They followed through with their proof of concept and brought to the table a PROPER public test phase. Not trying to make a profit model for a game that stays in alpha/beta forever (at this point).

This is the stripper model of FPS games and I love it. It also has the same vibe we saw in classic Unreal Tournament and I'm not saying that because it runs on Unreal. It also runs amazingly smooth.

It truly is a back to basics classic arena shooter. It's a proper pickup and play as well given the streamlined menu setup. Brings back the nostalgia of my childhood after a minute of gameplay.

I'd recommend this to anyone who grew up with UT or any of the game prior to the Halo/COD-baby generation!! A MUST.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a review for the Early Access version (v0.7) of the game. So far, it includes 1 map which can be played in deathmatch and team deathmatch mode. There are 7 weapons with alt fire modes, and no vehicles.

A few things to know before you buy this:

1. The balance of weapons is off. If you look through other reviews or the official forums, the rocket launcher (Cerberus) is widely believed to be highly OP.

2. The skill level of some of the players is quite high. You will get fragged, a lot.

3. There are already cheats available for it, which can alledgedly fool anti-cheat protection employed by Valve.


Still interested? OK, this game is somewhat promising. I can't claim it's worth $17 at the moment, but there's some potential here. Notable features include an activatable and rechargeable cloacking device and pretty good graphics. It's also a pretty stable release, I haven't had crashes or glitches.

It still lacks something" to distinguish it from UT2k4

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although Toxikk is early access, and doesn't have much to offer at the moment, it promises hours of good fun, and if the devs stay true to what they have promised, I can promise you that Toxikk will be a game that you can't ignore.

Toxikk strives to stray from the other modern shooters, in fact, it seeks to bring back the Arena style gameplay from the late 90's and early 2k's by eliminating the reloading system, the health regaining, and the levelling systems. Now, being an arena shooter, it is extremely fast paced, from the movement to the short, yet brilliant encounters with your foes. forcing you to FRAG LIKE IT'S 1999".

Being a fast paced Arena shooter

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me preface this by saying this: I want this game to succeed. This game really does have some sweet, polished fun. But the fact of the matter is that I only was able to play one game before I had the game repeatedly crash on me. To the point that I came to make on this review: devs, please fix the crashing issues, as I can't write a good review for a game that I can't play. I cannot reccommend this game until these crashing bugs are fixed.

EDIT: 1/29/2015

After a much needed update to fix some issues with crashing I have to admit that I really like the action of the game. It's still very limited play though as there is only one map to play on and two game modes. I hope they come out with new maps and game modes soon. Also weapon and vehicles would be nice as well ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recommend this game, for any FPS gamer, and esspecially for those hardcore arena FPS types who usually play Unreal or Quake, this game is awesome.

Movement feels great, and that's one of the main things to get right for an arena FPS game like this, so good job Toxikk on that. As well as the gunplay, guns are satisfying to kill people with, especially with the sniper rifle or shotgun, but that's just me.

Very satisfied with my purchase, and they're going to be adding a lot more content as time goes on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is exactly what it looks like and what they say it is. if you're looking for an ultra-fast-paced, old-school shooter, get it.

Also, these devs understand Early Access better than most. Rather than release a 0.0001 and expect people to bear with them for an eternal alpha, they have a beta whose biggest changes are balance-related. There is currently only one map available not because they decided to build 10% of a product and ship it as is, but because they want to make sure the weapons are balanced with as few variables as possible before they turn on another slew of already-created, yet-to-be-100%-polished content. They currently plan to have the next massive wave of content released around February 12, following the last of the major weapon balance tweaks.

Great gameplay, great performance (!), great devs! Can't wait for more.
